reviewText:
Early Access Review

i REALLY recommend giving this game a shot, even if you tried it before. i didn't really like it until i gave it another chance like a year and a half after i first played. the game play at first seems odd, which is why i felt turned off the first time i played. the mechs aren't particularly towering in size and tend to be quick on their feet. when inside these zippy little robots you will be presented with a first-person interface. the window you look through leaves much to be desired in terms of visual scope. mastering the controls that allow you to turn quickly and maintaining a constant eye on your radar are key to getting past this flaw. basically it's a mech game that plays more like a fast paced or duck and dodge/ parkour infantry FPS. it's got the class system, TDM and capture point modes, fast combat, people calling you a noob from the other side of the world, etc.

just be warned that although it isn't P2W, in fact the game strikes impressive balance for the most part and all competitive items can be bought with play time earned currency, you will be at the mercy of a time-consuming grind if you want to access the 16 different mechs you don't get upon starting the game without paying any money (you start with 1 out of 17). there are also a few different weapons that can purchased for each mech (not a terrible variety, but it gets the job done). there are also consumable items and internals" that are basically accessories with combat functions. if you have a lot of free time like me
date: getting a dozen different mechs without paying can be a lot of fun. there is a lot of variety in the mech choices.\n\nthe other half or so to this is the community. for the most part the community is very friendly and happy to help new players. part of this is because of HAWKEN's highly diminished player base
recommended: as veteran players yearn for a growing community. the low player base also causes game balance issues as it's very easy for new players to be matched up with experienced players who will wipe the floor with the newbies. honestly the game itself and the mechs seem to cohere really well
hoursPlayed: but it needs a lot more people playing so that the player base isn't all veterans scaring away new players that don't get a chance to catch up. when you do have a balanced game it is a lot of fun though

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is great! It has big potential to grow into something big after the Early Access.

So, basically this is a FPS game. You are inside a mech and you have to destroy your enemies. There are several game modes, such as deathmatch and capture-the-base style. You can check the discription of the game for more details.
There are 3 types of mechs: Light (high mobility and less health) Medium (Everything medium) and Heavy (high health and less mobility). Every mech is balanced and it's really fun to play with everyone of them. You can customize your mech in almost every aspect. There are points you gain after every match and you can spend them for buying new mechs and to upgrade their weapons. But here is one thing - you can pay for other points if you want better visuals, or to unlock an upgrade early (it will unlock anyway, but at level 3,5,10 and ect.) which is your decision to make, if you have money and want to support the developers. It's not one of the pay-to-win ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ts out there.
The graphics are good. The sound is good. I don't know anything negative about this game at all. Honestly, this is one of the best free to play game on Steam.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is rather stagnant and dead at the moment since the developers pretty much disappeared off the face of the Earth, without any updates or notifications whatsoever since the third quarter of 2014.

To play this game, you pretty much have to learn to adapt to a new style of playing different from that of a conventional first person shooter(Battlefield, Call of Duty etc.) It forces you to rethink your strategies since teamplay is an essential aspect in team games, requiring you to coordinate well with your team mates and working together with them to win the game unlike BF or COD where solo-play in TDM is a norm.

Overall, a real eye-opener as to what mechanical first person shooter games are capable of - fast paced action, explosive weapons etc. It offers a wide array of machines(we call them Mechs") that are each suited for a different role
date: hence it does up open up for many different play styles to be incorporated."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAh HAWKEN... I've been playing this game since Beta and it's absolutely gorgeous. Fast and fluid. Intense and gritty. If you're looking for a fast paced mech' combat fps, this tops the genre. It allows you to play fast, furious, and twitch without suspending the disbelief that you are piloting a massive combat robot. So many things add to the flavor. Different mechs have different abilities, different classes of mech provide differences in speed, health, and weaponry. It's a little more polished and refined than it was when it was still the independant indie game that hadn't yet been picked up by Steam. There are things I dislike, such as getting rid of the skill trees, but it truly is better off in the long run. It's also free to play! There are in game purchases, but if you put a little time in you can buy your own mechs with the in game currency quick enough. You just have to know what game mode to play. I suggest Seige. Collect and return all the EU you can to get mad money. Game modes: Deathmatch, Team Deathmatch, Missle Command, and Seige. Deathmatch I does not need an explaination. In missle command, you have to capture nav points basically, which are essentially giant missle turrets that shoot at your enemies mother ship. In seige, you collect energy units, or EU, and return it to base in order to launch your teams mothership. Once launched, your team has to defend the only anti-air turret on the map so your mothership can go and pummel the enemies base, whilst your enemy is trying to do the same to you. Stunning graphics, fluid gameplay, great musical score and sound fx... and it's free. What have you got to lose?

date:

- Game claims to be all about aim but has lock on rockets that rarely miss even when the didge is timed properly. Doesn't matter though most teams stack 3-4 of these mechs and a "medic" class and the game becomes a boring peekaboo fest. Hard to die when an enemy can't dodge your main damage weapon unless they're facehugging you.
- The old HUD is gone and has been replaced by a BF4/COD clone.
- The new reticle is just this side of invisible.
EDIT:
- VOIP is still broken after a year of being "a priority" for them to fix.
- Clan system is still non-existant after 2 years of empty promises.
- Friends list wipes randomly every few weeks. And has since
recommended:
forever.
- They fired their competitive side guys so it's unlikely we'll see the promise competitive style Hawken that has been boasted all along.
- They havent released a single new skin since the first closed Beta.

Honestly all of this games issues boil down to laziness or incompetence. I prefer to say incompetence because if people are too lazy to fix the thing that's going to be making them money. Well then damn that's just sad on an epic level. I really think someone else did the initial development

The game has stagnated from its high hype debut in 2012. The dev team has no clue which way it wants to go with anything and the overall feel is one of incompetence. Just let this title slide right by you I loved this game so long ago and tried to force myself to love it again. It just isn't worth it."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First review on a game I really enjoy.

I have been a long time fan of computer games since Doom and Wolfenstein 3D. I have played all types of computer games and I have followed the Mech Warrior franchise as well. There simply is no comparing any other game (including mechs) to Hawken. It is simply one of a kind and has its own genuine feel like Team fortress 2, Don't Starve, or Jedi Knights II Jedi Outcast. I strongly recommend downloading it and playing it for the experience alone if nothing else.

I played Hawken during the first 3 months of open beta and took a break until January this year and have been playing ever since. From my 3 months of experience with the old game developers, Adhesive Games and Meteor Entertainment were incredibly slow to respond to the community.

Right now, the new developers are completely different. Developers from Reloaded Games have jumped on teamspeak and have had several Q&A sessions with both long time devoted members of the community and more casual players like me. You can find these sessions on youtube and twitch. The forums have been restored, mayhem and fight club servers are running and I have definitely noticed a rise in the population. The new developers have been very active in listening to the community.

The developers say what they do and do what they say."

The new developers ask for the community's input to make important decisions. They explain their current line of thought
date: outline preliminary expectations and options and set reasonable deadlines for community feedback usually around 3 days to a week depending on the issue. They follow up. The developers say what they do and do what they say. They act based on our feedback and their expertise. I am very optimistic about what the next 3 months will bring as the developers work their way through the code.\n\nThe game has relatively low complexity but amazing depth once you figure out the basics(dodging
hoursPlayed:
using cover). You are given the CRT starter mech that is essentially the strongest mech in the game. I have only mastered this type of mech (CRT/Assault) but I have been actively trying other mechs. Each class of mech feels completely different from one another in terms of strategy but the basics are still the same.

Game modes include the typical deathmatch and team deathmatch but also include missile assault (capture and hold) and siege mode where you collect energy to launch a ship that deals damage to and ultimately destroys an enemy base while you fight for control for an anti-air turret that brings these ships down just as quickly as they launched.

Seriously download the game (for free) and try it out. Hawken is an amazing gem that deserves at least a try.

Thanks for reading and I hope you found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played HAWKEN for a long while, and have periodically dropped in to revisit it. I think that I should give this game some credit - as a game, it's superb. The design and style of the mechs, the maps, and the GUI make for a very immersive feel, as they all slot together so well; the depiction of the HUD as the inside of the mech also really puts you in the shoes of who you're playing as. Fights are very, very intense, with often entire teams full of mechs saturating a single capture point: flying over one another, swiftly dodging attacks, etc. - there's so much to take in, all at once, and it's brilliant!

The mechs are cleverly designed in aesthetics and otherwise, being appropriately balanced, and also, having an entire arsenal of unlocks to compliment the strengths of your mechs. The classes a varied and defined, and this game can cater for all playing styles that we typically see in a modern FPS. Furthermore, there is a good sense of personalisation for your mechs, because you can choose which retrofits, (or interior mechanisms), you'd like to install on your mechs to aid you in battle, and also, changing the appearance of your mechs is also easy, for a small price. The customisation options are very broad, from simply changing colours, to completely replacing your thrusters and hull!

HAWKEN has a series of interesting game modes that it has to offer, from simple deathmatches, to attacks on bases that can last up to half an hour - sometimes more, and each game mode can have varying pace and intensity of combat. While I personally feel that HAWKEN could offer more in terms of game modes, I can appreciate the situation that the current developers are in, (it's quite a sticky one), and can also enjoy the excellent modes that we already have.

So, for an Early Access game, this one is fantastic. It really is. It feels so nice to play, everything is smooth and well-oiled, and the design and customisation elements of the game are superb. HAWKEN has to have one of the most well-continued and expressed art styles, (resembling something dystopian) that is consistent throughout all areas of aesthetic design, that I have ever seen, and as an FPS, well: it's fun, it's fast, and there's a heap of classes that you can choose from and kit out to your heart's content! While the developers are having a difficult time at present, and the game is indeed lacking in some areas, it's kept me coming back, and so many others too. For an F2P EA shooter, this is astoundingly good, and great fun to play!

I'd give it a good 8/10, for now. I'm sure that, given time, that score will increase! Good luck HAWKEN, and good luck to those of you who start playing! You won't regret joining!

The new developers are doing better than I originally anticipated, so props to them.
They're from Reloaded, but are their own individual branch".

In overall it's pretty good aside from the small playerbase."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my first FPS that isn't Metroid Prime or Portal. I have little experience with games like this, apart from 2 hours playing CoD Black Ops at a friend's house. This is a really fun game, with the best soundtrack ever. I still barely understand how the garage works, and am still getting used to most of the manuvers. Also, the chat settings has a profanity filter (thank god) and most of the time the people you play with are nice anyway. I only own one mech (I think...), but you can take others out for test runs. But the thing is, if your computer is slow, you will have lag like you won't believe. My computer is probably below average when it comes to speed, and sometimes it runs really smooth, no problems, and sometimes it lags to unplayable, even with the lowest video settings.

Overall, definitely get it unless your computer is slow, because I get the feeling someday it will be a paid game, it's that good.

Oh, and P.S.  You need a Meteor account to play. It's easy to sign up and they don't email you constantly with updates, like Skype does. (ugh). You need to log in every time you play.

P.P.S. As it needs to sync your account and stats before you can start playing, it takes a few minutes to set up if your computer is as slow as mine, but it is well worth it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game isn't perfect. There are not many people on any servers except the north american one, so that forces me to play with a high ping (I live in Australia). Playing with a high ping is difficult in this game because of its fast-paced nature, but I did spend a reasonable amount of hours doing so. Also, the matchmaking sucks, but it does give you the option to pick a server for yourself which I find very handy. You can't play offline, and to finish that off you will need a reasonably good graphics card to run this game 1080p 60fps, especially on the map 'LAST ECO'.

Now for the good things about this game. There are a variety of game modes, and I enjoy them all. Team deathmatch, Deathmatch, Seige, Missile assault, Co-op bot destruction, Co-op team deathmatch etc.
The graphics quality is awesome. It looks amazing.
The community may be small, but it is good. The players are often courteous and active, and people who idle are kicked automatically. Some people say that the mechs are unbalanced. Well it's not the dev's fault you're just s**t, is it?
The devs have made the game in a way that all mechs are equally balanced, and they also all cost the same amount. People are just good at different types of mechs.
I personally love the reaper mech because it is fast, accurate and it causes a reasonable amount of damage. But if 3 or 4 rockets hit you you are done for. To compensate for this you can boost in all directions to confuse your enemy. Or you can put up a tactical shield or put down a turret. But in a way all mechs are like this. They have their pros and cons. I've seen every type of mech own the field.

Overall this is one of the best games that i've played. The game mechanics as well as the wide variety of classes just seal the deal.
Nothing beats strolling around in a giant humanoid tank.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

HAWKEN is one of those high quality F2P games that suffered from poor management in the beggining which ultimately stopped it from ever becoming seriously popular despite the games high quality. The main issue was that the countermeasure system used to be a PvP thing instead of strictly PvE items, which caused a lot of pay-to-win controversy. And honestly, it was. A person who payed money could then funnel all their leftover XP into countermeasures for a noticeable advantage. They eventually learned and finally removed the system from competitive PvP play, but it was too late. The damage had already been done.

The game has now unfortunately faded into another one of those obscure F2P titles that only has a couple hundred people playing at any given time. The game now stands as yet another example of how F2P with bad business models can ruin their reputation forever, regardless whether or not the problems are later fixed.

That being said, the game is still a lot of fun and filled with life. Graphics are well done, gameplay is extremely well designed, there are plenty of customization options for your mechs, and the business model is no longer pay2win. It's worth a try. Just don't expect any major competitive scene or tournaments with cash prizes on the line.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Some things to know about this game:

Nothing is destructable, not maps, not mech parts.
Infinite ammo, there's no ammo mechanic aside from rate of fire.
There's no idea of armor.  Seriously, everything is life based.  Hitting someone in the arm, leg or body all has the same damage effect.
Limited customization.  Check the website, everything you see there is exactly how it is.  Every mech gets 2 guns, one of which is swappable with a limited number of options (1-2 alternates).
Using micro-transactions, you can make any mech look like a different model mech.  This makes battlefield identification pointless.
Visual distinction is kind of funny.  You can unlock one alternate model and one camo for each mech.  Everything else must be purchased.  The funny part is that you cannot use the camo on the alternate models.

This is not a mech game.  It's a standard fps with jetpacks where your player model happens to be shaped sort of like a mech.

Hawken is not a bad game.  I spent $10 to buy into the early entry and played it up to 14 hours a day during a week waiting for a different game to release a new content patch.  I don't feel like I want a refund, but I also don't feel like it's worth much more than $10 or more than a casual play style.

Overall: extremely underwhelming

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's FPS shooter where you'll ride a robot and shoot the hell out of your foes who ride robots as well. What could be better than riding a badass robot and start shooting stuffs to each other? The answer is—you guessed it—this game: HAWKEN.

Not only cool, this game is also well-balanced and really fun to play. There are several mechanics and quirks that need some reading to know how it works, but essentially they're simple enough to learn.

The tutorial is also very helpful. It gives you some essential stuffs and make sure you've got a hang on your ride before you hit the roads, like how to detonate the Assault-class rockets in mid-air or doing a 180 spin, which is now being my main tactic of maneuver after getting used on it. Maybe it sounds like any other tutorials in any games, but where else you'll be guided through the tutorial by a chick? (lol)

I have a tradition of trying every available classes in any games, but as I write this review I don't have trying the heavy-class mechs (and from this point I'll call the robots as 'mechs') yet. So far I stick my butt on a Reaper-class light sniper and everything's just right; the speed, the maneuver, the weight, the effects, everything. Switch into Predator-class stealth-ambush raider and see when you acitvate its ability. Very neat.

The developer would say they're polishing this game, but as far as I've seen, every of the aspects in the game are well done. The graphics are breath-taking although I have to get used with the terrains and stuffs to spot enemies ahead.

Talking about the mechs, all I can say is dayum these are the rides I'm looking for!" However
date: there are still lack of custom frames and other customizations especially in mech designs and weaponry
recommended: although the developer has given some options to choose. Just my opinion

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fun for a little while until you realize that nothing you buy for one mech transfers to another mech.  So, if you are a gamer that likes to switch classes, you are going to spend time grinding until you unlock enough HC (earned credits) or outright buy MC (purchased credits).  All the upgrades are cool, but they are definitely trying to entice you to skip the grind and paying cash for the game.  Screw that.  I bought into the Nemesis pack thinking that I'd unlock everything like some other games (*cough* Tribes *cough)... essentially paying for a full game to help the devs.  This is NOT the case.  You get a partial game.

Example: sucks seeing other players air dodge but you can't because you haven't purchased that particular unlock.  Screw.  That.  Noise.  If I wanted to switch to a different mech, well, pretty much everything I've bought" / earned in-game does not transfer to that mech.

Pass.  Done playing.  Enjoy the money I blew on this lousy game

Damn.
I loved Hawken soooo much. It was probably the only game I was excited of lvling up and getting better guns and honing my skills. If they revive the game, and the player base comes back up, I'm sure to get back into the game.... I'm just depressed how Hawken shatterd like glass. I strongly reccomend to try it out though.  Its a whole new experience.

Actually I am now back in the game!!! The last developers drove the game to the ground, but new developers have picked it up!!! They are coming up with game some game improvements and more content. Keep in mind though, that the new devs will need some time to bring the game back into full action. They are in the process of fixing bugs and other problems from the last devs.  Go play it!! reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has been part of my library since the december of 2012, when the closed beta was released. the E3 of 2012 got me hooked when they announced a F2P game based around giant, hulking mechs blowing each other to bits. They stay true to this basic concept, and because the art style is based on improvised robots, they made all of the weaponry/armor/speed seem like it was all just thrown togeether with duct tape. That, is a true testament on how well thought out this game is.

On the down side, the early access on Steam feature made it not Free to play for new players. This is because Meteor Entertainment, a small, indie game company, needs to expand it's servers to accomidate the sudden tsunami of new players coming from Steam. Thus, they made it not free for new players. It was free, however, if you signed up and played in the closed beta. Sad times for new players.

:C

Anyways, overall this game is awesome for a guy who was raised around Quake Arena and/or Unreal Tournament, for it is fast-paced and intense. The good news is that there are next to no campers, since the 'camping' prospect is only reserved for those who are in Sharpshooter and/or Reaper mechs. Outside of that, you cannot destroy other mechs by yourself. You have to work as a team to secure your victory, since the other team is doing the same. If you don't work together accurately, the other team (who is usually accutate and coordinated,) will reach the max kill limit of 40 before the 10-minute timer is up.

If you can, and if you are impatient, then I would definetly reccomend this game before and anfter it's official launch.

Happy fighting!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a great game.  This review is done durring early access.  This game feels done and ready for release.  Lots of fun.  Very well ballanced.  This game is not pay to win and I love that.  All weapons and all mechs are available to all players with XP from just playing the game.  There is a cash store in the game but it is very well ballanced.  Thanks HAWKEN.

Lots of different mechs (classes) that you can play.  Great ways to customize each mech.  You can switch between all of your mechs on each death.  This alows you to adapt very well in each match and maybe turn a game around.

Combat is awsome and all the classes are balanced very well.  The game is free.  Why read my review when you can just install this game and try it out.

Maybe you are frustrated with Titanfall.  Maybe you are wondering why Titan fall is not as good as you had expected.  Maybe you should try HAWKEN.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am a alpha player in Hawken . This is a game i love to hate . After several thousand hours of game play on 2 different accounts I believe it's time to let it go . This journey all started for me back in 1995 after i purchased a black with blue trim IBM PC . I also played a mech game that I just loved to play . Years went by and I searched from time to time for a game like the one i remembered from the past and MWO just didn't fill the bill for me. Finally there was hope and I got an invite to be a alpha tester in a game that looked all too promising , Hawken is the game I had been searching for all these years. Beautiful graphics , stunning physX effects and some really great guys and gals to play with online , to all of you it's been my pleasure to play online with you all and all of you have taught me something so thanks for the best GG's ever.

Unfortunately for me this game has the biggest balance problems I have ever seen . I have litterally watched it unbalance it's self 3 to 4 times in the same game setting. Most games are one sided and you either win big or loose big . I agree it has gotten somewhat better but balance has a long way to go .

I played this game with 2 - 770's 4gb in sli and frame rate drops are crazy , I would go from 121 fps to 60 even 50 fps for no reason and on my monitor there was a definite difference in game play. Optimization sucks for my hardware and no I don't have this problem on other games I play , it is Hawken Optimization .

Conclusion : This a great eye candy game with a wonderful community and neat experiance but now I must do my job as a tester and say I can't recommend this game due to the balance issues and optimization that i was hoping for to be repaired by now , since 2012 when i first signed up.

You guys may still see me from time to time but for now I need a break from all the issues this game has . I don't think i'll see it as my go to game anymore rather something to do when I'm board or just a reminder of a game I wish it could of been.  I will truely miss you great players.

Thanks for your time
Littlebuck0211 / Ol' MechDonald

Early Access Review

Interesting twist on Arena PvP and COOP games, especially if you like Mechs :)
Game looks really good with fast performance. Concept is straightforward with this kind of games, but there are  a lot of modes to play in coop, or pvp or even free explore. Also it has fast gameplay that is fluid, and matches last no longer than 10 - 15 minutes.

Yes it is full of microtransactions, but most are cosmetic though I saw a majority of powerup items requesting purchase, but  I think its NOT fully pay-to-win type of game (cant go in details and explanations now). There are a lot of powerups, upgrades, items and cosmetics stuff you can apply to your favorite mech - system looks complex enough!

You can jump-in and play it casually or totally competitive and thats why its fun and easy to get in to. Thats why I recommend it even though I do not like this type of arena pvp microtransactions games ;)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ever since TF2 started to betray me with various technical difficulties, I've been forced to look around Steam for new multiplayer experiences. I tried RoboCraft and grinded that for about a few months (Was fun until tier 6). Then my brother made me buy Strike Vector which is enjoyable in those very rare moments when there are people playing it and NOT constantly dominating you with dual rocket launchers. I've also played the Sniper Elite V2's multiplayer but that's funny for about a half hour up to an hour. Two hours if I listen to music at the same time. Sadly, I was getting bored...

But then I discovered HAWKEN. A game about mechs fighting each other with guns on their arms. You might have heard of Mechwarrior Online and you might be more interested in that rather than HAWKEN. But HAWKEN is like Mechwarrior's less realistic brother/sister, however, that doesn't mean HAWKEN is less fun. In fact, I really enjoyed HAWKEN because of its in-detail tutorial that explains mech movements that you can develop and master over time. Also I found it really easy to get into, but difficult to be really good at. That's pretty much my vision of TF2. Easy to do

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Oh god, where do I even start with this game. I am pretty much addicted to playing Hawken and find myself hard pressed to find another game to play that is as fun. I have been playing pretty much every day since Open Beta came out and I love it. The game has evolved and changed so much and yet still stays true. There is nothing like the speed and thrill of running around in an scout (the fastest, least armored mech in the game but hits like a sledge hammer). You can move and fight in ways I have never been able to ever do in any game before.

On top of that, the community is amazing. They are all by far the best of any game I have seen. Everyone is willing to help and jump in. Most of the players are kind and have great sportsmanship. There is nothing like getting a GF (Good Fight) after a hard fought battle with someone.

If you want lots of action, skill, fast paced, crazy trill FPS game, then Hawken is for you. However, you have been warned. This game takes some skill to be good. Don't expect to jump and play like COD. You will die a lot if you don't basically throw what you know about an FPS out the window and start over.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is the most wonderfull Robotech Ego-shooter game i have ever seen, at this time (it is still in Beta) it is so balanced, and nobody ever calls out to someone else beeing noob for using speacial mechanics or weapons or items.

The community isn't big but is nicer than in many other shooters. You barelly get insulted by other players and this game represents teamwork as a big word. Basically walking around alone and not helping your team mates wont make you get kills, only deaths.
Also this game gives you something I really missed in most shooters i ever played, it's the XP when getting kills or assists, but this game divides XP not by that, but for the % percentage you deal damage to the enemy. so at the end, it becomes balanced. Killing an opponent by dealing 3% of damage will give you far less points than assisting by 20%.

ALSO, TO PEOPLE WHO KEEP SAYING THIS IS A TITANFALL FAKE. IF YOU CHECK THE RELEASE DATE, YOU WILL NOTICE THAT YOU WERE WRONG. THIS GAME'S ALPHA VERSION WAS RELEASED IN 2012.

So at the end this game is great awesome, and requieres more players and fans!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a fantastic mech game; it makes me feel like I'm playing Battletech. The controls take some getting used to: turns are slow, and the repair mechanic takes some getting used to. This is definitely not a mindless pick up and play like Team Fortress 2. The game is gritty as heck, and unless you work together, you don't live long. This is not a game for heroes.

The community is actualy a good selling point. HAWKEN has such a small userbase, it's really chill, and 'gg' is really common in the after-game chat. Even though there is a cash shop, the game is not really PTW, as everything can be earned through normal play, and quite honestly, if you pay to get the best mech without leveling up, you'll get crushed really fast.

12/10 will keep playing.

Well I have been playing Hawken pretty regularly since April 2013. In this time I have found a game that satisfies many wants I have in a game. Anyhow at over 400 hours of play I still have a desire to play often, become a better player and I recommend it to anyone wanting a free to play game that is not pay to win. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hawken used to be a great little game that stood out from every other bland fps on the market. However much has changed since the open beta back in 2012, and not for the better. The devs seem pre-occupied with adding superfluos content, rather than addressing key issues which would help this game attain a solid following, and keep its old fans.

If you're located in the U.S and don't want to play too often (the more you play the more you will find yourself locked out of servers due to your skill - a crippling feature for a game with a small fanbase like this), you may enjoy it. Overall however I simply can't reccommend Hawken as it is in its current state.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Most people say Free to Play FPS' are doomed to be Pay 2 Win. However HAWKEN proves the exact opposite, being a Mech-shooter where seeing the earliest Mech in the game; a CR-T Recruit can be twice as frightening as seeing a 1000 pound Vanguard rushing at you if the pilot is skilled enough.

Compared to most games which identify as Mech-simulator the Mechs feel fast, agile and extremely responsive. Not to say there isn't a clear difference between light and heavy mechs, but said difference only adds to the realism and immersion of being a Mech-pilot in the world of Illal.

One tip:
Use a mouse and keyboard; adds ease to dodging and aiming which is complicated by a gamepad.

One piece of criticism:
The UI colors which you can choose from in the cockpit customization can conflict, which is quite confusing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is probably the best multiplayer mech game ever released to date.

One of the problems with traditional mech combat games is how slow and clunky mechs generally tend to be. While it's cool that these tank-like mechs are all powerful and filled with weaponry, the combat tends to be fairly boring and slow paced compared to regular FPS shooters. With HAWKEN (silly name for this game, imo), the devs have designed some much faster mechs with more agility. Even the slow heavy mechs are fast by normal mech warrior standards. And unlike in traditional mech warrior, the little fast mechs can dish out a ton of damage, and don't have misguided weight class restrictions to prevent a heavy weapons loadout on a fast mech. The lack of armor and survivability is handicap enough.

So while the HAWKEN guys have done a good job at giving the game an FPS feel, the game still has the traditional control problems and vision limitations of your typical mech. While some people will be delighted to hear this, I personally would just like to see some kind of GUNDAM anime style mech combat where you can share the instant response controls and high visibility as you would in a normal FPS. As it is, you must rely on your radar to be aware of the battlefield, and depend on your team to cover your blind spots. Great for pre-made squads who intend to play this game competitively, no doubt, but not ideal for solo players running into a team of pre-mades.

So in conclusion, HAWKEN takes a mech warrior game to an almost-FPS level, but still keeps some mech handicap traditions alive to make the game still feel like a mech game. Does it succeed at being a good FPS? In my opinion, not really. And does it succeed at being a good mech game? I'd say yes, but mostly because I feel every other mech multiplayer game out there has failed at what it set out to do.

HAWKEN gets a 7 on 10 from me, which is a great score for a mech game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is truly the most excellent mech game I've played in years.

Basically every time the devs change something (even the oft-reviled Technician), it seems to be for the better.  I've been enjoying it more and more the longer time goes on.

HAWKEN's long TTK and heavy handling (read: there is a turn rate maximum), positioning and teamwork become even more important than they are in other offerings.  The mechs feel like mechs without feeling incredibly clunky, the weapons feel punchy and satisfying, and there are very few things in the game which are just better than other things.  It's rare for me to find a game wherein I have so much trouble choosing a favorite class/weapon/etc.

This game is great.  Play it.  Give it to other people.  It takes a long time to unlock things for free, but they're making its F2P shop better every day, and both mech fans and shooter players will absolutely get their money's worth out of one of the mech-unlocking bundle packs.

The newbie mech that you get for free?  I still pilot mine and top charts in it.  The CRT Recruit is loaded with weapons that are easy to pick up and remain potent in the right hands without getting ridiculously overpowered; it's sturdy, relatively quick, and has one of the most potent sustained firefight abilities in the game as well as literally the most flexible main weapon.

Play this game.  Play it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

HAWKEN straddles a tightrope somewhere between a bona fide mech simulator and a CoD clone in Mech Cosplay.

But this is to its credit. This game is a real gem injecting a novel dose of atmosphere, innovation and nuance to a fairly stale genre.

There is simply no reason why any Steam user should not have this game in their library. It's free to play, painless to register/log in to and really delivers some epic skill based and team orientated gameplay.

The microtransaction model is used strictly for cosmetic items only. Everything else can be acquired using the currency earned from playing the game (albeit this is rather obnoxiously slow as expected).

It's hard to believe this game is still in beta as it could be released on shelf tomorrow as is for $39:95 and it'd still be worth it.

About the only thing lacking right now (aside from perhaps some minor balance issues) are user controlled dedicated servers and a hardcore S&D style gamemode (Team vs Team, 1 life only, no respawns, with the vanquished spectating the survivors). Currently the only modes are Deathmatch, Team Deathmatch, Missile Assault and Siege which though all well realised play in an arcadish kill/die/respawn/repeat type manner.

The maps, though truly individually awesome, are rather few in number and HAWKEN could certainly benefit from a good deal more of them.

These two quibbles aside though, HAWKEN is a visceral and refreshing FPS with some really slick production values. These mechs don't lumber around awkwardly laying waste to cities on the horizon, they're more like athletic exoskeletons which lend themselves wonderfully to traditional twitch style LOS competative FPS gameplay with some genuinely interesting mechanics and (intended) limitations.

Install now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Awesome idea, poor execution. In mech games you are supposed to use tactics to kill your opponent. In HAWKEN the highest damage comes from fast mechs with SMGs. Instead of tactics, you have people corner peeking then running in and walking in a circle while holding their left and right mouse buttons down.

I'd really like this game if one mech and one play style wasn't better than everything else, but sadly it is.

It also doesn't help that this game has a healing system where you run away, press C and heal up. Those SAME mechs that can slaughter almost all other types are the same ones that can easily run off and heal. They also had the genius idea of making killed mechs drop a cube that heals you, so the same mechs that can slaughter pretty much all other mechs can literally fight non-stop.


As of writing this the game has 141 players. The game is dying, and it isn't because it isn't known. It just sucks.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Favorite game of all time. If you like mechs, robots, sci-fi, tactical fps, or blowing stuff up, then I highly recommend this game. It's free-to-play, with gorgeous graphics and visuals, immersive sounds, and fast-paced mech warfare.

There is nothing cooler than battling in a giant war machine with guns. The gameplay is smooth and fast, but you really feel like you're inside of a hulking mass of metal and death. There are plenty of mechs that you can accumulate and pilot, each very distinct from eachother.

Being free-to-play, you can choose to spend real money on paintjobs, alternate body pieces, different repair drones, and faster mech and weapon unlocks. That's it. You can't buy yourself a victory; it's all in the pilot. Everything besides purely cosmetic items can be unlocked through playing the game. You don't need to spend a penny in order to be good and have fun!

This game is quite fun, easily the best Free To Play I've seen in recent years. Before it was on Steam I also played it, it's the exact same game, just carried over.

Graphics are great
Soundscape is very nice
Combat is balanced and rewards skill
Is not Pay to Win
Fun/competitive gameplay
*HAD* a good player base.

That last point is not to discourage you from playing the game, just be wary that matchmaking will take longer, and realize that this game is no-longer in its prime do to it being online only.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's about the only f2p game that I have enjoyed so far. The mech combat feels great, the game looks awesome, and it feels a lot less 'grindy' than a lot of other games, even non-f2p games like BF3, which is sad when you think about it. I have unlocked 4 mechs since it has come to Steam, with about 10 hours of playing. The starter mech is grand, and there are also mechs available to 'test drive' so you can try before you buy.
I am happy enough to just play and use the in-game currency to unlock mechs for now. I haven't spent any real money yet. Though I could see myself spending a bit of real money on this as it is a genuinely good, polished and well optimized game.

I am really not a fan of grinding, so I wouldn't recommend it if I felt it wasn't worth your time. I got into the 'early access' for free because I already had an pre-steam account with them that I transferred over. If you hadn't played the game before, looks like you will have to wait a bit while they transition onto Steam unless you want to pay for 'early access'.

You could have played the game at any time before now for free and transferred your account over too, so not much point in complaining about that now. Just wait a bit and it will be out of early access and f2p.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

By far my favorite game! i have over a hundred games and i still play hawken daily over a year after getting into it. glad they brought it to steam, but it's probably a little too late?

the developers have made poor decisions recently in the way you customize your mechs, in that you can no longer change how they function every mech is the exact same but you can pay for different upgrades which are one time use tools each life. such as a turret, radar jammer, shield, etc.

because of this you are rather limited in play style for each mech, a class is speed, c class is heavy, b class is mixed and but bad at both.

fortunately because of the lack of customization though, it is not at all a pay to win, every player has a relatively even playing field and it's all based on skill.

the only things you can not unlock by gameplay is visual options such as paint schemes and mech parts.

also, you earn points after each round, win or lose, to spend towards unlocking items for your mech, you progress very fast in this game and learn a lot of points! you don't spend hundreds of hours grinding, points are abundant and items are cheap keeping you playing.

unfortunately for the developers though they are way over pricing their visual upgrades, it would cost you $10 for one paint job on one mech so i literally never see people who have paid real world money for anything.

hopefully they tweak their monetary levels so it's not so steep, it would bring them more money which would bring the fans more game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Mecha games have been steadily on the rise in popularity. However, Hawken stays pretty true to mecha roots. You pilot a mech in first person and do battle against other players or bots. Using strategy and firepower, you can easily gain the upperhand in any match.

There are dozens of customization options per mech. Dozens of machine guns, cannons, and rockets will help you find the best way to nuke your enemy. And with multiple mechas to choose from, all with their own abilities and customizations, you can amass and army of mechanical monsters to wreck other players.

Design wise, I like the game's futuristic junky feeling. As a fan of Gundam, I'm a little tired of seeing glitzy, shining mobile suits. These mechs look like thye were scraped together to fight in overgrown factories and bombed out cities in the wastelands. It makes you immersed with environment that justly suits your chocie of mecha.

All in all, its a really great game. Its relatively easy to pick up and you dont need to play obssesively to become a good player.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is essentially MechAssault meets Unreal Tournament. There aren't really any other games quite like it. It is free to play, but actively avoids being pay to win (unlike MWO). Diehard mech simulator fans should consider other games, though those of you who like Unreal Tournament and giant bipedal walking machines with guns should give this a try. Adhesive Games is an excellent developer, and the game gets updated regularly with new fixes, mechs, and cosmetics.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIt's a free mech FPS with RPG elements. What more do you need to know? It's fast-paced and it encourages interesting an new strategies as you get better mechs, get better at your mech, and explore the maps. It's a F2P game, but I've never felt like that meant pay to win. It's balanced enough that I've never seen someone who was invincible due to having too good of a mech, and as a tanky mech, I've still died to good low-level pilots. Skill matters a lot.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

HAWKEN is a first-person shooter where you control a variety of different mechs to battle other mechs. This may not be a very original idea, but the game itself is very well done.

Like all F2P games, it features a ton of unlocks - however, it is quite fair in this regard. Cosmetics can only be bought for real money, which isn't too big of an issue, and while you still have to unlock everything besides the starter mech, the amount of time it takes is reasonable and can be done quite quickly. The game features a variety of different mechs, items, internals, all to customize your gameplay style.

I would say this game's learning curve is pretty steep, actually, especially for people who are used to standard FPS games. The mechs handle like big hunks of metal, since, well, they are big hunks of metal. There is a cap on how fast you can turn, and they are quite big, and their movement speed is quite limited. While they can still use their thrusters to do some fancy moves, getting used to stiff controls takes a bit of time. Also, the game is very team-focused, so you're going to fail very easily without some general teamwork.

The graphics have post-apocalyptic feel to it - which is completely in-universe, considering you're basically fighting for one of two corporations struggling to get valuable resources on an already doomed planet. They fit in with the style of the game, which is what I value the most about graphics in any game.

HAWKEN, despite being still in beta, is very polished and presents almost no bugs.
Overall, this game is a very good experience. I recommend it to FPS players and mech lovers alike.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Want an awsome mech game that relies heavily on teamwork to win but where actual teamwork is a rarity? How about a game where the skill level is so high that most new players will constantly be on the losing team and die a lot untill they get 50-100 hours of game time in before they start getting the hang of things to be able to compete in mid-tier games?  Look no futher than Hawken.

I used to recommend this mostly team-based game to anyone, but now it's riddled with players who do not try to do objectives or help their teammates out. This isn't a game where a player can be an all-star and save the day. Teams win by teamwork and lose horribly when they do not. It is really a shame because this game can be awesome when people are trying to be team players.

It also doesn't help that the game doesn't reward teamwork enough. A prime example would be the lack of points awarded to players for assists. right now killstealing rewards players more points than doing most of the damaging but only getting an assist.

When you are lucky enough get in a match where both teams are trying to do the objectives, it is very fun regardless of who wins. However, most games end up being complete landslides because 1 team is working together and trying to do the objectives and the other team (save 1 or 2 players) are avoiding doing any team-related actions such as capturing and holding points, collecting and returning energy units to home base to launch our ships, or even helping each other in firefights.

Players not trying to help their team or trying to complete objectives makes no sense. Playing with such stupidity is absolutely zero fun. I hope the new development team can tweak/balance Hawken to encourage and reward teamwork.

I would also like to add that cheating is and has been a problem since around the time Hawken arrived on Steam. Mostly wallhackers but I've seen blatant use of aimbots as well. You can easily find recent videos of hackers on You Tube and Google searches. When Adhesive was doing well, they were active with banning cheaters. Now it goes unchecked. Although, Reloaded just got rights to the game and has been making significant improvements. Time will only tell.

Frankly, after sticking with this game for so long (since just after alpha)  I am at the point of giving up on it. It's more hate than love now. There are valid reasons that Hawken just can't retain its player base nor capture and keep the interest of new players with the big learning curve and poor teamwork that runs rampant now. Time is better put into other games that reward players of all skills levels which are much more relaxing and less punishing. It's truely a shame as the potential for a AAA game is definately there.

To get hawken credit, you can get them by spending time playing on it but it is quite a grind. All the lanscape/area is a amazing warzone scene. Many player are pretty mature and friendly. reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a game crafted by those passionate about gaming, first person shooters, tactical combat, innovation, and most importantly... MECHS. These are not your average walking battletanks. These weapons of war have tighter controls, quicker movement, and devastating weaponry. The combat is fast paced and heart racing. The customization options not only change how your mech operates in battle, but also make each mech your own. And you can have many mechs in your garage. I've been playing since alpha (over 300 hours logged) and have seen Hawken in all of it's iterations - and every single one has been a blast to play. HIGHLY recommended. Don't let the learning curve steer you away and don't think that this is some 'indie' game (though it is) because it is AAA+ calibur. Join us and I hope to see you on the field.

~N0stalgia

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been playing Hawken since closed beta and before it even came to Steam.

Graphics: They are good but not amazing. Not much to run this game, even though they give you tons of options but ultimately make no difference I seen.. Max graphics super smooth!

Audio: Big mechs walking around, shooting futurist weapons, shields, oozing and so much more in this game. Really makes too feel like it's all there.

Controls: Actually make you feel like it's an FPS game, seriously easy to use and play.

Game: It is a multiplayer mech fighting game... Not so much fast paced as such but there is some fast moving at times.  Otherwise it's kinda mixed slow and fast, actually depends on your play style. It is quicker than Mech Warrior and in some ways better.  I enjoyed the original mech warrior multiplayer but the new online just was not as good as I thought.
Hawken offers something things mech warrior does not and that for me is a winner.

There is a lot to unlock, customise and so much more to do.  The game packs a punch for content and is free to play so it's a huge steal.

The overal gameplay of this game is good, you will have lots of fun playing this game alone against people, and you will have just as much fun with a friend.

The game modes are nice and there are new ones coming now and then.

There are purchases which sound like micro transactions but the way the game is handled, trust me it's not because you can destroy mechs with the worst gun while they have the best gun.

This game is about thinking while attacking. You cannot just attack a brute without taking steps or approachs to win that battle.

Anyway worth the time and some money for some credit to buy small stuff.

Would I recommend? Yes why not.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hawken is a game that will bring out the best and worst in you. There are times when the game is a glorious battle for supremacy and gives great satisfaction on winning an encounter, and others where it will frustrate you to the point wanting to break your computer in half. It will reward you if played with strategic thought, and punish your mistakes in a brutal gladiatorial spectacle of wreckage.

While one can quickly get a handle on the general mechanics of piloting the different mechs, it may take a bit of time to begin to master them all, and the learning curve at higher levels can be steep. The design over the last year of the beta phase has had many shifts and bumps on its road towards completion, but for the most part it has been fun playing, testing, and watching its growth.

Overall I like the game, but I feel that it needs more time for polish than it is going to get before release, and could use a bit more content in the form of different game modes and maps. More content is on the way, according to the developer, but I find myself impatient in expectation of expanded play options. At present though, I believe a majority of those who join us on the Hawken battlefield in the next few months will like what they see and will have a mostly positive experience.

See you in battle,

RipperT

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hawken is a great game, but not as a FTP. Here's an in-depth video review with my reasons.

http://youtu.be/TvzBWwPvF38

In summary, here's some of the pros and cons.

+Fun gameplay. You really feel the weight of the mech you're in and all of the feedback.
+Large variety of interesting mechs to help you find your playstyle.
+Weapons and mechs are mostly balanced. Everything has a strength and weakness attached to it without one being flat-out better than another.
+Nothing quite like it anywhere else. It's different from other FPS's because of you being in a mech rather than a person. Lots of interesting situations arise that make the game feel unique and stand out from the rest.

-Very grindy. It takes about 8 hours of non-stop gameplay to purchase the most expensive mechs with in-game currency. There are some that are cheaper, but a lot of them come at a high price.
-Slightly PTW. You can use real money to buy internals and items that give you an edge in battle. You even can unlock them early only by using real money, as opposed to spending 8-30 hours of playing to unlock the best stuff in the game.
-If you are FTP, you ONLY start with one mech. While it isn't any better or worse than the others, it only offers a limited playstyle that may not suit your needs.
-No true way to test drive a mech to see if you like it. You're stuck with that mech if you bought and can't get a refund. While there is a feature that grants you unlimited test drives of 1-2 mechs weekly, you're unable to customize it the way you want and are locked with only that. Gambling 8 hours worth of work is too much of a risk to find out if you actually do like the mech you're gonna get.
-You feel locked into one particular mech. You accumulate experience with that mech and unlock different loadouts with only that particular one. All the internals and consumables you buy for hefty prices are also locked onto that much only. It feels like it's punishing you for choosing any other mech because you have to start from scratch.
-No way to fully customize your mech. One thing that really irks me is that your secondary weapon will always be locked.


Overall, I think the game is still worth a play, but I highly recommend you buy the nemesis bundle if you truly want to best experience. Otherwise it's too harsh on FTP'ers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(First review!)


Short but to the point~

I found this game through the Free to Play catagory and I have to say, I am quite impressed. The reason this game caught my eye was actually (for any of you old school gamers out there from back in the 90's when PC was starting to make itself a name in gaming for once) because it reminded me of the original Mech Warriors. I have still yet to be able to find a game that compares to it, but this one comes close in a few ways.

PROS:

The first thing I notice right out of the gate is the graphics. I'm one of those people that if I have the capability at playing on Ultra (which having a GTX770 it isn't a problem), I do. This game seems to have a pretty nice flow if you have a chance to take the time to look at your surroundings in between trying to kill or be killed. I certainly know there are better visuals out there, but for an online game, they didn't have to dumb it down into the toon" like visuals similar to WoW (sorry to have to mention this game
date:
but it's the best explanation for my comparison). Usually game developers go easy on the graphics when there is multiplayer involved for performance. Hawken stands out to make itself an exception. The game developers seem to have done their best to make it seem as life like as possible. You can really get yourself to believe you're in the cockpit manning that mega war machine. (Provided you have the right rig set up)

Once you have played enough and reached a certain quantity of currency (forgive me I have only played for 3 hours and forget what they call the point system) you have the option of buying new Mechs or customize the one you are currently running with. This adds more playtime to find out what you love running with as your set up and can dominate the best with. It's always best to have options over limitation.

Playing multiplayer is really fun. Who would only want to reap destruction by themselves? Matchmaking seems to populate as expected; slightly slow at first but not too long you could finish a book. Being a Free to Play
recommended:
this is pretty typical as far as I can tell because not as many people take up the opportunity as they should to experience new things.

CONS:

The absolute thing that I believe first to be on the list is that this game does not seem to have a campaign. (Game developers I apologize in advance if I have missed something
hoursPlayed: but I just can't seem to find it if it does exist.) Multiplayer is fun and all
voteText: but I love games that have a story too. Something to give the game more of that background some of us look for and place the relationship of the game world and multiplayer together.\n\nThis is not a complaint on my part
helpfulPercent: but I list this simply because I try and keep others in mind for their experience in play
votesHelpful: but I am going to mention the menu when it seems you're back in the "Bay". There are certainly a lot of things to cycle through and it can potentially seem a little overwhelming for thos whom wish to jump right in. Not to say you are unable to
votesTotal: however if you kept up with this mentality you would surely meet your demise and lose interest in the game as everyone is upgrading and you are not. Also checking out your stats as well as others. The game certainly goes in depth for those of us checking profiles
votesFunny: but too much info for the casual player will steer them clear if they don't know what they are looking for.\n\nBack to customization
commentsCount: I personally wish there was more. It seems that a lot of the upgrades you get are linear for the level of the Mech as you play through
column16: i.e. legs
column17: body and weapons. Again
column18: I have only played for roughly 3 hours and may not have achieved something that I am unaware of but for the time being it seems to only have one path. Most of the custom comes from the additional consumable items or slight "boosts" for your Mech in battle. I probably grade too harshly as mentioned before I compare this to the original Mech Warriors
column19: but in Hawken you only seem to have two weapons. One long range
column20:
and one short. I really would like to see some additions made where you could have up to potentially 4 or more to diversify battle a little more. Adding that would make it more enjoyable in my opinion.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
As mentioned
column21: short and to the point. Overall
column22:
I do enjoy this game and certainly hope they have further output in future updates to bring further hours of enjoyment. I give Hawken 3/4 stars.


Let me know what you guys think? Agree or disagree to anything I mentioned? I'm curious to know what other players think."

A friend, who has played Titanfall, recommended HAWKEN- and it was one of the best recommendations ever! After putting in over 4 hours straight in this game, I'm very pleased. Great graphics, excellent gameplay, friendly development team and community. Yes, there is some grinding involved to earn credits to buy or unlock items- but you can purchase credits to expedite the process. However, the game is balanced so well that even the medium starter" mech will more than hold its own against the purchased mechs. Lots of upgrades and customization available too.

This is a mech game where "maul and brawl" don't work as in other mech games- so you have to re-learn/adapt to using agility

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do you prefer eastern mecha games, where the mechs are nimble and dances around while exchanging rounds on the battlefield? Or do you prefer western mech games, where the mechs are lumbering machines where strategically hurling rounds is the best way for you to avoid an explosive death? Hawken is an odd blend of both and you should give Hawken a try.

Do note that Hawken is NOT a mech simulation game but a very arcade-style first person shooter, and a darn good one at that. If you’re expecting sluggish machines overloaded with weapons in slow-paced combat then look elsewhere, you won’t find it in Hawken. The mechs in Hawken looks like they’re made of scraps and (in the current patch) falls apart like one, forcing players to play smart. Prepare to get toasted if you try to run and gun. Strategically approaching a target will ensure you don’t get scraped before dealing some serious damage. Once the players get close, prepare for some really brutal combat. Reading your opponent’s moves to dodge shots using your thrusters while landing skilful shots will ensure you emerge the victor.

The mechs in Hawken fall under three classes: light, medium and heavy. Light mechs are fast and agile, but has armour made of Kleenex. They can stay in the air the longest and dance around in combat to toy with the larger mechs, but drops down within a few shots. The heavies are well-armed and has the ability to soak the most damage out of the three classes. The mediums are between both classes, being the jack of all trades in the classes. All mechs have their distinct strengths and weakness, where they can be all deadly under the right hands.

In terms of the weapons, all mechs in Hawken carries two weapons into battle. Each mech has three primary weapons to choose from and a secondary. Each mech start with one primary when purchased and other two unlocked based on the rank of the mech.  Despite the solid mechanics of the shooting, the unfortunate case is that most of the weapons are boring but practical to use.The latest mechs however carries new and strangely fun guns, hence I believe we can expect more interesting weapons and variety as the game development progresses.

Regarding the F2P model, I find that the developers have done very well in that department. All mechs and parts can be purchased with both in-game credits and micro-transaction, so you won’t be locked out if you don’t pay. The grind for credits is also quite short as compared to other F2P games. The only things locked out for non-paying customers are cosmetics, which offers no advantages except for the mech chassis. Some players use micro-transactions to turn their mechs to look like a completely different mech which tend to cause a lot of confusion in battle. Thankfully, these players are really few and can be dealt with appropriately once you know about it. The other minor complain is the odd pricing of some skins, where apparently giving your mech a coat of solid black cost more than getting two new guns. Other than these two minor complains, the micro-transaction model of Hawken is fine, and absolutely not pay to win.

To sum up, Hawken has its up and downs. Looking back to the fifty plus hours I’ve spent in the game, my experience have been all pleasant. The game is certainly not what I expected it was, but still excellent and fun to play. I would totally recommend to give this game a try.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hawken is a gem of a F2P title! It's a fast-paced mech game with a good amount of variety among the different classes, beautiful graphics, a neat backstory and old-school shooter gameplay.

An important note to make from the start is that it isn't P2W; the stuff you can buy with only Meteor Points (the RMT currency) are cosmetic items or XP/ingame currency boosts. All mechs, weapons, internals and items can be unlocked by playing the game. The starter mech is very competitive and it's not uncommon to see newbro's placing high on the leaderboard at the end of a match, having levelled up several times over!

Hawken places an emphasis on player skill rather than what gear you're using. If you know the playstyle of your mech well and can work with your teammates you'll go far. People who expect to be able to drop some real cash to unlock mechs and own everyone will be left with a bitter taste in their mouths.

I've been playing Hawken on-and-off since January 2013 and I always keep coming back to it. The universe is great (I heartily recommend the prequel" comics as they're a great read) and the mech designs and environment visuals are beautiful. The  Hawken community are also mostly awesome - having lurked on the official forums for some time there are multitude of player-written guides and helpful folk around. Even ingame you usually get friendly and polite players chatting between rounds/deaths though if this will change with the advent of the Steam transition I can't say.

Overall
date: Hawken is a fun game that puts the onus on player skill to win
recommended: rather than the gear you're using. It's extremely fast-paced  and because it's free you should definitely give it a shot!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Back in June 2012, I joined the Hawken community after being accepted into the alpha phase of testing. I soon after met up with fellow Digirev members Gatnic3 and GuGz. in my time in alpha I have tested many mech variations. In all of alpha testing, one mech load-out seemed to reign supreme! it was the then named Assault load-out with the Mobi chassis type. it stood its ground over and over, time and time again. it was the predominate favorite for most pilots in the alpha test. That very same ultimate load-out is now the Fred CRT-Recruit starting mech. this means that the most well balanced and well rounded mech for most situations is the starting mech.  you may ask yourself, why is any of this relevant? Well Edubs is here to tell you why! You see in the Latest Major Patch, amongst other things, the Hawken team decided to remove tuning points from the game entirely! So we are now the closest we have been to the Alpha build of the game since we began Closed and Open beta. Its just Raw stats and skill now with no more variables. the only thing we can change are Weapons, Internals, and Item load-outs.

This is great news for the new player in Hawken! it means that you have a fair chance of winning once you master the familiar controls. Hawken’s controls do not vary from standard FPS placements. you see the common WASD movement and standard SHIFT key Sprint/Speed Modifier. Ctrl for VoIP, E to Interact, Q to Spot. Space to Jump/Jet Jump, F for Ability, Z to Call for Assistance, and C to Repair. In fact these controls are very similar to the controls of another popular F2P game on steam, Planetside 2.

It is also really easy to level up and unlock additional mechs in Hawken. After 3-4 matches you should have a few more to choose from.Hawken is primarily a PvP game, but If players don’t want to jump into the PVP combat right away or you are looking for a place to catch a break from the action, you can join a Co-Op Bot Destruction match. Co-Op Bot Destruction is a great place to practice your shooting and teamwork skills as well as a place to meet other players in a more social setting. Just a warning though, Co-Op Bot Destruction does get pretty intense, so don’t let it fool you! Of course you can purchase consumables to help you beat the waves but its optional and not necessary and in my opinion makes it less fun.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFor someone like me who has been into Action skill-based FPS games since I was 7 years old; I find this game Hawken" to be a refreshment to the nostalgic days of FPS competition. While it holds some nostalgia
date:
it also takes some great elements from modern shooters without eliminating skill-based gameplay. This game is like taking Tribes 2 and marrying it with Quake 3 Arena while holding some class diversity seen in games like Team Fortress.

Pros:

+ Mech-based combat.
+ Class-based units to choose from.
+ Customizable loadout and gear.
+ Thoughtfully designed maps.
+ Skill-based and fast paced.
+ Coop mode included for wave after wave type fighting.
+ Enjoyable competitive field.

Cons:

- Has some F2P elements such as a market.
- Doesn't have surround or eyefinity support. (This is controversial).
- Has the potential to have a overwhelmingly amount of gear variation; giving some people the inability to make tactile decisions.
-Has the potential to get rollercoaster balancing based off COD whineboys.

With that said
recommended: I really enjoy this final beta; I hope this game has a bright future; but with it I hope the developers AND publishers observe and study some of the critical mistakes that other AAA companies made such as Planetside 2 from SOE or Tribes Ascend from Hi-Rez. The key to a long-lasting and superb competitive game like this is to carefully make the decisions."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

HAWKEN is a very fun, arcadey robot shoot-em-up. There are a surprising number of interesting game modes (though not as many maps as I'd like to see, at this point in development), and a fair number of neat robots, weaponry, and abilities. Gameplay is simple arena-style for the most part, with plenty of explosions and bullets whizzing about, and with the unique abilities of different mechs adding a bit of variety for different playstyles. Overall, it's fun and engaging, if a bit simple.

I do have some pretty noteable criticisms, though. The grind is extreme, if you haven't bought the starter bundle (which is a pretty fair value, all in all). Unlocking new weapons and robots takes a very long time, and cosmetics are cash-only. There's also not much in the way of non-cosmetic customization. Each mech has one special ability, one non-unique secondary weapon that can't be changed, and a choice of three non-unique primary weapons (that need to be unlocked through grinding or real-money). This feels a bit arbitrary. It makes me wonder why they didn't actually let you BUILD your mech, by choosing from a wide variety of parts, abilities, and weaponry. The only customization to speak of is choosing which of your selected robot's three primary weapons you'd like to roll out with, after grinding to unlock one of a rather uninspired collection of cookie-cutter prebuilds.

I'd recommend the game, because it really is fun. The core gameplay is there! But it's not a very high recommendation, because of the huge amount of missed potential with the gimpy customization system. I'd give Hawken a 3/5 in its current state, but changing simply changing the customization system to one that let you actually assemble your very own mech would make me reconsider that rating in a big way.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do you prefer eastern mecha games, where the mechs are nimble and dances around while exchanging rounds on the battlefield? Or do you prefer western mech games, where the mechs are lumbering machines where strategically hurling rounds is the best way for you to avoid an explosive death? Hawken is an odd blend of both and you should give Hawken a try.

Do note that Hawken is NOT a mech simulation game but a very arcade-style first person shooter, and a darn good one at that. If you’re expecting sluggish machines overloaded with weapons in slow-paced combat then look elsewhere, you won’t find it in Hawken. The mechs in Hawken looks like they’re made of scraps and (in the current patch) falls apart like one, forcing players to play smart. Prepare to get toasted if you try to run and gun. Strategically approaching a target will ensure you don’t get scraped before dealing some serious damage. Once the players get close, prepare for some really brutal combat. Reading your opponent’s moves to dodge shots using your thrusters while landing skilful shots will ensure you emerge the victor.

The mechs in Hawken fall under three classes: light, medium and heavy. Light mechs are fast and agile, but has armour made of Kleenex. They can stay in the air the longest and dance around in combat to toy with the larger mechs, but drops down within a few shots. The heavies are well-armed and has the ability to soak the most damage out of the three classes. The mediums are between both classes, being the jack of all trades in the classes. All mechs have their distinct strengths and weakness, where they can be all deadly under the right hands.

In terms of the weapons, all mechs in Hawken carries two weapons into battle. Each mech has three primary weapons to choose from and a secondary. Each mech start with one primary when purchased and other two unlocked based on the rank of the mech.  Despite the solid mechanics of the shooting, the unfortunate case is that most of the weapons are boring but practical to use.The latest mechs however carries new and strangely fun guns, hence I believe we can expect more interesting weapons and variety as the game development progresses.

Regarding the F2P model, I find that the developers have done very well in that department. All mechs and parts can be purchased with both in-game credits and micro-transaction, so you won’t be locked out if you don’t pay. The grind for credits is also quite short as compared to other F2P games. The only things locked out for non-paying customers are cosmetics, which offers no advantages except for the mech chassis. Some players use micro-transactions to turn their mechs to look like a completely different mech which tend to cause a lot of confusion in battle. Thankfully, these players are really few and can be dealt with appropriately once you know about it. The other minor complain is the odd pricing of some skins, where apparently giving your mech a coat of solid black cost more than getting two new guns. Other than these two minor complains, the micro-transaction model of Hawken is fine, and absolutely not pay to win.

To sum up, Hawken has its up and downs. Looking back to the fifty plus hours I’ve spent in the game, my experience have been all pleasant. The game is certainly not what I expected it was, but still excellent and fun to play. I would totally recommend to give this game a try.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hawken is a gem of a F2P title! It's a fast-paced mech game with a good amount of variety among the different classes, beautiful graphics, a neat backstory and old-school shooter gameplay.

An important note to make from the start is that it isn't P2W; the stuff you can buy with only Meteor Points (the RMT currency) are cosmetic items or XP/ingame currency boosts. All mechs, weapons, internals and items can be unlocked by playing the game. The starter mech is very competitive and it's not uncommon to see newbro's placing high on the leaderboard at the end of a match, having levelled up several times over!

Hawken places an emphasis on player skill rather than what gear you're using. If you know the playstyle of your mech well and can work with your teammates you'll go far. People who expect to be able to drop some real cash to unlock mechs and own everyone will be left with a bitter taste in their mouths.

I've been playing Hawken on-and-off since January 2013 and I always keep coming back to it. The universe is great (I heartily recommend the prequel" comics as they're a great read) and the mech designs and environment visuals are beautiful. The  Hawken community are also mostly awesome - having lurked on the official forums for some time there are multitude of player-written guides and helpful folk around. Even ingame you usually get friendly and polite players chatting between rounds/deaths though if this will change with the advent of the Steam transition I can't say.

Overall
date: Hawken is a fun game that puts the onus on player skill to win
recommended: rather than the gear you're using. It's extremely fast-paced  and because it's free you should definitely give it a shot!"
