reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game. Don't trust the metacritic score of this because it is an awesome game! Great mech warfare, fast paced, and strategic!

For a free game, you can't get much better than this. There's 4 main multiplayer modes and a co-op horde" mode. The 4 multiplayer modes are deathmatch
recommended: missile assault (essentially king of the hill type style)
hoursPlayed: and seige. Seige is the most unique. You gather energy and go back to your base to deposit it. There is a bar on the top of your team's score that shows how much energy is required to release a giant ship to attack the enemies HQ. Once this giant ship is released
voteText: you have to either shoot at it (takes forever) or fight for the anti-air platform somewhere on the map to dispose of it again. Then it starts all over again with energy gathering. Essentially
helpfulPercent: it's a race to see who returns the most energy and releases the giant spaceships the fastest. Very unique.\n\nThe mechs cost a lot
votesHelpful: and the "currency" earning and XP is kind of slow
votesTotal: but I guess they have to make money off of this somehow since it is a free to play since they offer experience and currency boosts for some money. Each mech is unique in its own way
votesFunny: so I would research the mechs to see which ones are worth spending currency on (that way you don't pick a mech and waste all that hard earned currency on something that does not fit your play style.)"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Probably the best Mech game released to-date, Since Titan Fall isnt a Mech game! I have to say its alot more fun than Mechwarrior Online from my view. The gameplay reminds me alot of Star Conflict for some reason.

Hawken,
Is more of an arcade Mech game, Focused on having fun, while keeping things simple and user friendly. As much as i hate COD, i have to say that the game play compares to a COD game, In regards to Its purly about having fun. This game uses Pre-Build mechs that you can customise: Weapons, Equipment, Passive Perks, Decals, Consumables. However all the Mech Parts such as legs, torso, Arms and so forth are all cosmetic and have no effects when changed.

Mech Warrior Online,
Toke a more realistic approach due there old day roots they had with the original Mech Warrior games. However i just fund it alot of hasttle and wasnt alot of fun for me. Mech Warrior Online has alot more customization though and you can build your own mechs from scratch to how you want it.

This being said both games are brilliant and unique Mech games and are both worth checking out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Where do I begin with HAWKEN......I played HAWKEN before it came to steam and I am happy that it is, but i cant see how to download it for free without buying one of the game packs? I had to use a code they emailed me for playing before it came on steam anyway....HAWKEN being a free to play game will have its limitations like all free to play games, HAWKEN's being customizing your mech and no campain to speak of. Parts for your mech and paints jobs is where you will be spending your real money, unlocking mechs is actually not as bad as some free to play games.. yes its still a drag in HAWKEN but you can unlock all mechs in game without spending a cent, you do this by maxing out certen mechs levels and leveling up your player. It offers players in game cash for playing, getting challenges done and winning matchs... then you can take this in game cash and downright buy a mech. Most of the cooler better mechs are 12000ish credits, about 5-6 hours of game play worth to get. It is no where near as bad as trying to get credits in  Mech Warrior Online ".

Gameplay is VERY! fun.. it being a first person shooter and all mechs really nicely matched in strangth makes HAWKEN   one hell of a good time. It can get repeditive but luckly it has many differnt game modes to choose from to keep you playing. Maps are laking but it is still in BETA ( going on what 2 years now ) so new maps will being coming with time. All in all I have never had HAWKEN glitch or crash for me it is very stable game! I Recommend HAWKEN to everyone and anyone who like shooters or mech games. But with Titan Fall comming out I can kind of see it killing HAWKEN
date: But if you dont want to pay $60 for Titan Fall HAWKEN  is a good FREE replacement for it."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFor a free game, it is definitely a good game to get a hold of. There is intense action all the way and it certainly gives you quite a few hours to occupy yourself. The graphics are great and there is hardly ever any lag. This game reminds me of some sort of Titanfall mini and I like it! Being only multiplayer although, I believe that it would be great if their were a singleplayer, or more maps... It definitely needs to be played moderately because in my opinion, it can get sort of boring if you play too long. Although, if you're someone looking to have some fun with some friends, it is a great game to pick up and it will certainly impress you for how good it is for a free game :).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very solid performance, slick graphics, some really good moments in the simplistic soundtrack, and shiny UI.

Combat is fast paced, clearly a PC game, where certain game modes can take teamwork and 30 mins or so. At the same time maps are somewhat small - remember this is a game based on smaller arenas rather than big open battlefields.

Balance is (almost always) very good, quite a few mechs to choose from, and some good combinations of abilities and items. However this game is NOT about heavy customization. You are given a mech platform, some tools to play with and change, and then you go into combat. You find the best combo, and kick ♥♥♥.

Rewards well played gambits, skilled players, good decision making and clever trickery, albeit on small/medium maps.

The pay model is a wee bit expensive for certain customizations, but on the whole is a bit fairer than games like Loadout or Rift, but not as cheap as Star Conflict, World of Tanks or War Thunder. The pay model is pretty solid as far as pay2win" goes
date: seeing as there are no premium mechs (at all) or special uber weapons available only to real money payers.\n\nConsidering the game is free
recommended: and takes about 5 minutes to get into
hoursPlayed:
there is no reason not to try it.


Solid 9/10"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is probably the best multiplayer mech game ever released to date.

One of the problems with traditional mech combat games is how slow and clunky mechs generally tend to be. While it's cool that these tank-like mechs are all powerful and filled with weaponry, the combat tends to be fairly boring and slow paced compared to regular FPS shooters. With HAWKEN, the devs have designed some much faster mechs with more agility. Even the slow heavy mechs are fast by normal mech warrior standards. And unlike in traditional mech warrior, the little fast mechs can dish out a ton of damage, and don't have misguided weight class restrictions to prevent a heavy weapons loadout on a fast mech. The lack of armor and survivability is handicap enough.

So while the HAWKEN guys have done a good job at giving the game an FPS feel, the game still has the traditional control problems and vision limitations of your typical mech, which helps turn the game from a fps with large robots to a emrsive well poished mech vs mech experence. As it is, you must rely on your radar to be aware of the battlefield, and depend on your team to cover your blind spots. This is great becase it encoreges teamwork, to use everyone’s strength’s to your advantage and to minimise the enemy’s teams ability to prey on your weaknesse’s, with small meches scouting and locating enemy mecks, medium meches acting as mobile firing platforms supporting the rest of the team and bringing on the pain, and the heavy meches to both take and deal large amounts of firepower.

So in conclusion, HAWKEN takes a mech warrior game to an almost-FPS level, but still keeps some mech handicap traditions alive to make the game still feel like a mech game. does it succeed at being a good team based mech game? I'd say yes. :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ever since I played Mechwarrior on Windows 95, I have had a special spot for mech games. During the 2000's, Chromehounds filled that void but when their servers got shut down, I had nothing for a long time. Hawken brings back the amazing feeling of a mech shooter as well as being familiar to modern shooters that are popular today. I am always skeptical of the free2play model, but Meteor pulls it off right where you can play the game to unlock the mechs, or drop a couple bucks to get what you want earlier.

I highly suggest trying this game out, the graphics are breathtaking, controls finely tweaked and it is still only the beta yet it feels like a full game as is.

and remember, watch your fuel meter.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nPut simply: Hawken is fun. Hawken is really, really fun. It's relatively fast-paced, has a satisfying long time-to-kill, and movement feels fantastic. Your giant robot suit feels heavy, mechanical, BIG, and yet fast enough to not feel plodding and clunky. Progression isn't the fastest, but you can be competitive even with the stock CR-T Recruit mech it gives you; exceedingly so once you upgrade it just a little bit.  The microtransaction stuff is fairly implemented and while I feel that disqualifies it from being categorized as early access"
date: that certainly is not a knock against the game\n\nFom low to high settings
recommended: Hawken looks really damn good. Fidelity may not be the highest
hoursPlayed: but the game's aesthetic
voteText: which is far more important than graphics
helpfulPercent: really really shines. It strikes a balance between gritty and grungy and polished and futuristic. It works
votesHelpful: and it works well even on a lower-end system.\n\nPlay this game. Seriously. It's fun as heck. The learning curve is steep right at the very start
votesTotal: but once you get a handle on the core mechanics after a few rounds

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you are good at and like First Person Shooters and PVP.  This is a Free to Play First Person Shooter MOBA driving big Mecha into combat.  This game is still in developement, early release.

There is a Bot Training map and Bot CO-OP TDM, for those that are new and need practice against AI.  New players now get an Assault mech for free.   They have rotating free mechs to try.   You can get everything gearwise by earning credits from matches, so not Pay to Win.  Many different maps.  Movement skills are good for defense.  Store sells everything for real money.

Cons:
Terrible matchmatching.
Laggy.
Too small playerbase with too many expert players.
Still buggy.
Developers keep folding.

Give it a try, you might like it, but i suggest not paying real money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game doesn't get the playercount It deserves.

Normaly I don't like free to pay games, but this one is not pay to win. And the time you need to spend in the game to get you up and running with other mechs and weapons isn't at all that great.

The gamefeeling is more like a powerarmour than a Mech, but it plays very well and has a lot of balanced content.
The matchmaking isn't that good, but its no problem finding a game.

The different mechs can be personalised with different weapons (3 per Mech) consumables and interior. The changes aren't that big in most cases, but can suit different play stiles. Together with the different mech-types there is enough room for tactical choices, but not too much stuff to irritate newcomers.

It has quite a few Match types (like DM, TDM, Missile Assoult evt.) and maps for coop and copetitive gaming.

It's definetly worth a try, if you like shooter and/or mechs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is very enjoyable. However, it does have some flaws, and at times it becomes a bit tedious to collect the in-game currency. Despite this, it is definitely worth the download, and as it is free, can be played for a couple of hours and then forgotten about.

Pros-

-It's a pretty good looking game. Textures are nice, and the mech designs are cool.
-It's not too difficult to learn how to play. However, it takes some time to learn the nuances of each mech.
-Each mech feels like a completely different play experience (If you like that sort of thing.)
-There are a decent amount of maps to play on.
-There are 5 different game modes, and there is co-op play.
-IT'S FREE!!!!

Cons-
-It's unbalanced at times. If you aren't used to playing the game, certain mechs become a pain to deal with.
-It's pay-to-win. Sure, you can get everything in the game (save for a few cosmetic things) with the earnable currency,          but it's going to take you a lifetime, and the guys who are willing to pay, will win out most of the time.
-The maps get really old. Although there are a decent amount of them, they get pretty boring at times. (This is my opinion, your mileage may vary.)
-The match making is TERRIBLE. I've played at least a dozen games where I've been on a team of level 3-4 guys, and the opposing team is composed of maxed level pilots.

Overall, I'd recommend the game. It's a fun, free experience, and if you can't afford a AAA title, this is a decent substitute.

Early Access Review

This is the story of every HAWKEN player from the beginning.

THIS GAME IS GREAT!

... Wait... where did the developers go?

*looks in the drawers* Developers?
*under the table* Developerrrrs?
Where did they go?

The problem with Hawken. They made a great game, and then the head of the company was walking one day. He looked down, and noticed a penny on the ground. It was tails-up. He picked it up half-mindedly, and immediately after he tripped on a pepple and broke every bone in his body, killing him instantly. But then his life flashed before him. He thought to himself, Huh.. I left Hawken in the steam store to be sold and never come out of early access... Eh." And then he died.

... Wait

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nHawken is a great game, especially for lan parties. Good combat system and a relatively active community make this great for casual gaming or competitive, though the match making system can be brain dead at times. I could be wrong, but it doesn't appear as though the game takes into consideration level or preferred mech when matching players up which can lead to some very unbalanced matches. The system also doesn't take into consideration the size of a map, so a game with only four players can get one of the largest maps. One more gripe is the developers haven't put too many updates since release so you get that sinking feeling that you're playing an incomplete game. If you're willing to overlook these shortcomings, Hawken is a great game that is underrated both by the gaming community but more importantly the developers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To be honest, I was not only not impressed, I was dissapointed.  I'm a long time mechwarrior, and had every interest in finding yet another way to scratch my mech itch.  But this, it was just pointless.

Everything you will get out of the game, you will get in the first 20 minutes.  The skill ceiling is abysmally low, I topped the game every game I played, from the first to the last.  The gameplay mechanics are shallow and unmeaningful, with regenerable health and no module destruction.  heat buildup is a slight attempt to add depth to the game, but fails miserably, as it is neither severe enough in its consequences, nor oncoming quickly enough to be considerable.

Furthermore, there are literally weapons that use built up heat as a powerful bomb that can be fired to eliminate large amounts of it instantly, therebye making unlimited, totally uninterrupted fire possible due to the unlimited ammunition available to all players.

To be blunt, it takes mechanics from call of duty, adds a jetpack, and THEN simplifies them even further.  There is simply no meat or reward for extended play in this game.  You're far better off playing Mechwarrior, where skill, customization, and gameplay mechanics are brought full to bear to bring you an experience that actually separates itself from the norm.

Also, this may be just a pet peeve, but the mechs are just plain ugly.  They look cobbled together, unprofessional, small and weak, and sometimes ridiculously reminiscent of CRT monitors, 50's television sets, and old-style washing machines propped up on legs and given a machine gun.  Hardly compelling, to say the least.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I paid up for the highest tier of Hawken's Founder program way, way back. After all the crazy changes they've made to the game, my account no longer has any of it's old stats, I don't have access to the Founder items I paid for and the game is basically a mess.

You can't even access the server browser immediately, since the game forces you to use matchmaking for an unspecified amount of time before it unlocks the server browser button. I've played Hawken more than anyone else I know, so this roadblock is a major annoyance. I'm constantly joining games that are already over and then the servers count that game as a loss. My stats are pure garbage now.

Hawken is an infuriating mess and I kind of wish I never had paid for this game to be made in the first place. Even Tribes: Ascend, which is basically a dead, unsupported game at this point, has a better user interface.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an incredibly reluctant no. I wish I could recommend it, but I can't...here's why:
(Keep in mind I did not spend any money on the game)

After eight hours of play I had unlocked my first mech (aside from the starter of course) and was really enjoying the game. I had finally put in enough time and skill for my mech (the Raider) to rank up - which unlocks stuff for that mech. I went to use the new weapon I had unlocked to discover that I still had to pay the in game currency (HC which is separate to experience) to unlock said weapon. I had, in essence, unlocked" the ability to unlock the weapon using in game currency. All the while the process could have been sidetracked in an instant by using real money.

The developers have designed it to take as long as possible for you to get any reward for playing the game. There are four different values - MC (bought credits) HC (in-game earnt primarily by time NOT skill) Pilot XP and Mech XP. Even in-game items like shields
date: grenades etc are consumable - if you use too many before you rank up you'll have to buy more.\n\nIn essence the game is great
recommended: but the progression model is broken - you either have instant access by paying (which ruins the sense of progression) or grind (in which the progression feels negligable). Whether you pay money or not you will get sick of this game; there is no way to feel like you are not being cheated.\n\nI did some calculations and worked out it would take 197 hours or so of gameplay to unlock every mech. There is currently very little 'try before you buy'
hoursPlayed: so your investment of time/money is always cold. That estimate is if you spend nothing on items or weapons which affect gameplay tremendously.\n\nIf you wish to take the other route
voteText: and pay

votesHelpful: search around. That's prety much everything (except cosmetics) but still...\n\nEven if you like this game so much that all of the above does not dissuade you...remember
votesTotal: this is a multiplayer game. Already on Oceania it is impossible to find games in all the gametypes. People (rightfully so) are not going to put up with this
votesFunny: so you will have to be content playing in a very uncompetitive environment.\n\nTLDR: $2000 money to unlock everything or 300+ hours and you need everyone else to WANT to do that as well to have people to play against...do something else with your life..."

Having played this game before it was on Steam it used to look a feel completely different. The maps looked grittier and mechs felt pretty heavy. The time to kill was much longer than it is now which is the first thing I will talk about, the current TTK is really short so very few if any mistakes can be made which isn't very appealing to newbie pilots. The old TTK allowed for more mistakes and made you feel as if you were in a mech and using stratagy to claim kills, now it hardly takes much to kill anything save for the Vanguard in turret mode.

Secondly, the cockpit. The cockpit showed your mech HP, fuel, items and such on monitors inside the cockpit which added a lot of immersion into the game. It made it feel as if you were piloting a mech and had to check your mech's vitals while being aware of your surrounding. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played Hawken in the original closed alpha; I have the skin to prove it.

I was really, really excited about Hawken because I have a deep, abiding fondness for mech games, from a youth watching Robotech and Gundam, and playing table-top Battletech and Heavy Gear games -- not to mention the electronic versions.

When I played the alpha version, it had a lot of problems, most of which we were assured were just for the alpha. The limited matchmaking, the tiny assortment of mechs and weapons, the utter lack of interesting customization. I just came back, after the Steam release, and sadly, none of these problems have been resolved.

Sure, visually it's a spectacle, and the game plays fine, for what it is, but don't be fooled: it's not really a mech game. It's an action deathmatch game that you happen to play with mechs. It has a lot more in common with TRIBES than with Battletech. If you're a fan of classic arena shooters like Unreal Tournament, then, give it a try, but you'll probably be frustrated with the mech-wannabe mechanics (heat and fuel, primarily, not to mention the artificially-limited maximum mousespeed.) Mech fans should stay away.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you asked me if I recommended Hawken before the Steam release (AKA Alpha), I would recommend it. Sadly, many classes that were once fun to play and easy to use now have been downgraded since its change to Steam.

There used to be modification points and many cool things. The devs say that because of more newbies coming into the game, there have to be some changes as it is unfair to have Lvl. 30s against Lvl. 7s in a deathmatch. Instead of making team balances better, the devs just made all mechs gained from Lvl. 1 have the same strength as in a Lvl. 27 players' mech.

I spent hundreds upon hundreds of hours on this game. It may say so otherwise. If you like some non-modular fps go ahead for this. :|

Also, get MechWarrior Online :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Gotta recommend this game. Skip below for a TL;DR.

HAWKEN is one of the best F2P games out there right now, it's even better than a lot of games that you need to purchase to play.

Some free to play" games are "pay to win"
date: but luckily HAWKEN isn't one of them. Here's a big
recommended: long informative paragraph to explain how real money is used in HAWKEN.\n\nAll of the gameplay related in-game items may be purchased with the in-game currency. To have enough in-game currency to unlock the most expensive mechs in HAWKEN would require you play for only a few hours
hoursPlayed: and several locked mechs are on rotation for the player to use even if they haven't bought them. Each mech comes with a different deployable item
voteText: and alternate/additional deployable items and gear can be bought with in-game currency or real money. The stock deployables that come on newly acquired mechs offer one use per life
helpfulPercent: and specialized versions of these deployables would allow two or three uses per life
votesHelpful: while taking two or three times the amount of inventory space
votesTotal: preventing you from using other deployables. These specialized versions need a lot of grinding to unlock
votesFunny: and can be unlocked early by using real money. This makes it so a person who just got the game could have three different deployables
commentsCount: while a person who paid for deployables or did a lot of grinding could have three of the same deployable. Initially I was bothered by this
column16: but I realized there's a 7 second cooldown after using items
column17: so three items can't be deployed immediately to offer any sort of advantage (additionally
column18: only one of one type of deployable turret may be used by a single player at the same time
column19: so there's no way to  pay to win and have three turrets out while the other guy only has one). Other than unlocking mechs and items quickly
column20: real money may be used to buy cosmetics. Gaining lots of experience in a single mech earns you free cosmetics for that mech
column22: all cosmetic changes to your mech require real money.\n\nF2P discussion aside
column23: HAWKEN's gameplay is unique and interesting. Compared to other first person shooters
column24: the time it takes to kill enemies is much higher in HAWKEN. This makes it so sneaking up on somebody might give you an advantage if he's alone
column25: but if his team is with him they'll simply turn around and out-DPS you. HAWKEN is technically a first person shooter
column26: and it has a lot of the same gamemodes as popular first person shooters do (team deathmatch
column28: control points). They might seem boring in concept
column29: but the higher time to kill in HAWKEN transforms them into a completely different experience. In TDM
column30: entire teams stick together in tight groups
column31: gaining or losing ground on the map while teams try to catch stragglers alone or take and hold a tactically advantageous area. It's pretty big contrast to mindlessly sprinting around a map and finding people to gun down!\n\nHAWKEN has a super cool unique gamemode called "Siege"
column32: which I've never seen before in any game. Two teams start out on opposing sides of the map. On the map
column33: there is an anti-air missile silo
column34: and two energy nodes that give energy units (your mech may store and transport EU
column35: and will drop EU on death). The first team objective is to transport enough EU from the two sites on the map to your base to launch a flying battleship
column36: preferably before the enemy team launches their own battleship. When at least one battleship is launched
column38: fixing the amount of energy on the map until the sky is clear of battleships. The second objective is to take and hold the single anti-air silo on the map. The team in control  of the silo will quickly destroy any enemy battleships
column39: and prevent their own battleship from being shot down by said silo. While the battleship is in the air
column40: it will constantly deal damage to the enemy base; the longer the ship is in the air
column41: and the closer it gets to the enemy base
column42: the more damage it will do. Occasionally
column43: both teams will launch their battleship
column44: even after the energy nodes have been locked. When both battleships are in the sky
column46: but the battleship with the support of the anti-air silo will win the fight. Additionally
column47: mechs on the ground can turn their own weapons to the sky to fire on the battleship as a last resort
column48: if capturing the anti-air silo is too difficult. The team whose base is still standing after the battleship bombings wins. All in all
column50: and I'd say HAWKEN is worth playing just for that gamemode alone.\n\nAlso
column51: HAWKEN now has a cute co-op mode for 4 players. It's nothing amazing
column52: but it's good for getting some experience and in-game currency
column53: as well as passing the time with your friends. Right now there's two co-op maps
column54: each with 25 waves. Every 5th wave is a boss wave
column55: with powerful enemy mechs to fight. The two maps have different boss waves
column56: which offers some nice variety. Co-op is sufficiently difficult without being too hard
column57: and teaches players that sticking together is best for survival (which is true in PvP as well).\n\nTL;DR: HAWKEN is a surprisingly good game. It's got a lot of unique and interesting features. It's dumbed down and faster paced compared to a more strategy-centric mech game like Mechwarrior
column58: but it definitely sets itself apart from other first person shooters with its suspensefully slower pace and emphasis on tactics. I'm glad it has come to Steam
column59: and you should give it a shot when it's released for free to the public in Q1 of 2014."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI really enjoyed this game for about the first 20 or so levels (max pilot level is 30). After that I found all my matches to be incredibly one sided due to the higher level players that have spent money on the game. True, you can unlock all the mechs, guns, and items by playing but all of these things are absurdly expensive in terms of the in-game earnable currency (hawken credits). For example, unlocking a low end mech will run you around 3800-8000 HC and opening new guns on these mechs will cost you around 6400 HC. You then have to buy items for each mech individually and these will cost you 640-5200 HC depending on the level of the item. You earn maybe 100-200 HC per game, not counting the 250 HC daily bonus for each game type. Thus, you can reach the end game levels without having more than 2 or 3 mechs unlocked and most likely won't have more than a couple alternate weapons and items unlocked either. I really enjoy the game play overall and the graphics are gorgeous but the end-game feels completely pay-to-win.

Early Access Review

Been playing this game since its Alpha Stage and i must say that they have came a long way. Better tutorial, more game modes, Mech feels more solid and heavy than its early stage & more loadouts to customize!

Pros:
- A solid FPS multiplayer shooter
- Great OST and presentation
- Good tutorial
- Feels like you're riding a heavy mech tank depending on class and body
- Customization in weapons & mech
- Skill based game that relies on reflexes and also teamwork

Cons:
- No capture-the-flag like mode
- No dedicated server

It's Free to play so its worth the shot and one of the must try games out there.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So this games metascore does not do it any justice at all.

I got started on this game nearly a full year ago and have logged probably 200 hours on it off and on since then. It has a smooth and intuitive set of controls that are easily picked up.

The HUD that you get in first person view is clean and not full of junk while keeping the aesthetic of being a mech game.

The graphics are clean and extremely detailed with plenty to look at in both the large and small maps.

Last of all when you are just starting out you don’t feel underpowered because the mechs are appropriately balanced even when playing against players of higher levels.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok. I love mech games. So when I saw this on Steam, I had to do my research on it so I wouldn't get my hopes up.
It looked pretty intense from what I saw and decided to give it a try. I have to say it was the best thing I did. This game is a lot of fun especially with good teamwork.

The controls are pretty much like any other popular mech game. So if you played Front Mission Evolved or any of the Armored Core Series, then you should get used to the controls here right away.

The graphics are really good and have lots of detail. Although I would have liked to see my mech in 3rd person POV to see the detail on it but sadly there is only 1st person view. :/

This is a great game and I highly recommend it for any mech fan. :)
voteText: 14 of 26 people (54%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

HAWKEN is pretty much the Mech game i've been waiting for. The only downsight is that it's main focus is multiplayer.
I highly recommend this game to everyone who likes either FPS games or mechs...or both!
If you're into competitive first-person shooters then you'll love this game.
To all mech fans: The gameplay is fast paced so don't expect it to be like MechWarrior. There's also no singleplayer.
It does, however, have a co-op mode so you can tear down bots and bosses with your friends if you don't feel like competing against other players.

The game will be free-to-play once it comes out.
Is it pay-to-win ? No. Not at the moment. I haven't spent a penny on this game and i've been doing really well. So far i've been dominating other players without a problem.
HAWKEN is simply awesome!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hawken is the game for the people who want a fast arena shooter with quite well done graphics.

Hawken is a very fast mech shooter game, maybe in the Indi-Genre, but mainly orinatated on Call of Duty but better! The Mechs have a very good felling, you do not have the feeling to be in a heavy mech, you just feel like a normal guy. The Mechs are all pretty balnced which means that the Mech with the heaviest armor (Brawler) is the slowest, while some with not that much armor are faster and harder to hit.
The Gameplay itself is very fast, and quite well done. All the Multiplayer parts are very balanced, the only problem you may get are teammates that are used the the Gameplay of Call of Duty, which means that they run everywhere wiithout looking, which gets me to the next point:
Tactics. Tactics are and essenction point of every mech shooter, due to the fact that you are a freaking mech meaning that you are basically a tank on legs, meaning that you should not run into battle without thinking (many people do that by the way). You do not really need that in Hawken, which i think is kinda bad. Tactics are not needed, because you have infinite respawns, meaning everything is more like Call of Duty.

You can reache very weapon wihtout investing real life money, even if it takes some time. Some cosmetics can only be reached by playing, others only by paying. That means that everything is awesome, even though that you may feel a little bit demotivated because the players that invested a lot of money are better" than you because their gattling-gun kills you faster than any other weapon on your mech
date: meaning that it can be unfair.\n\nTo summarise it
hoursPlayed: and it is nice to play occasionally in the evening.\nI can recommend it

helpfulPercent: and you can not loose any money. There are a lot of noobs in the game
votesHelpful: so you can get a KD of 3 pretty easy

depending on what mech you play and on your team.

DOWNLOAD IT! CLEAR RECOMMENDATION!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OMG YES... Seriously though fast paced mech shooter action, dashing properly (yea if you can do it right good for you because it seems like no one can and it's the key to everything) and thats a testiment to how important movement is in this game. Battles evolve completely minute upon minute and there's a good variety of mechs so you're going to get a different style of teamwork everygame. There's different mech rotations for trialing things you think would be cool and its free so why are you still reading this go download it already.

I was playing back a while ago and though some people hate the changes they've made I personally love them. They've moved the game closer to the fun but intense tactical arcade that it's meant to be than the everyman for himself mech-sim that it was becoming and I for one find that refreshing.

Oh and it's actually not pay to win. Though you can advance quicker with meteor credits or whatever the only things you can buy with them that you cant get with the normal currency are cozmetics. So no problems there.

Anyway just an all around fun and fast paced shooter which people actually do engage in teamwork in that you should all atleast give a try. I would totally recommend this, to anyone who likes mechs, and/or guns in general. :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fantastic game.  Great gameplay, fairly well balanced, beautiful graphics, encourages teamwork, decent maps and a fair number of them.  The  best AND worst part of this game are that its F2P.  A bit too grindy for me.  I'd like to purchase more mechs, but with the cost of upgrading using XP based credits, i don't see myself playing this game for too long.  I'd be more inclined to spend money on cosmetics in these F2P games if they made more of the actual game accessable without spending money (they are free-to-play, yes?).  They're certainly not helping themselves with the current grind-or-pay-to-play model they're using.

P.S.  Here's a little write-up about F2P models in general, and the authors opinion of them, with specific examples given in relation to Hawken.  Sums up fairly well why I dislike F2P.  I have no problem paying for a game, but when you do the math with most of these free-2-play games, you realize you'd be spending hundreds of dollars on in-game currency to open up even a portion of the content, as opposed to the traditional $40-$60 (ignore the new DLC model of stealing from schmucks for what essentially the community used to be able to create for itself for free).  I would LOVE to pay $40 for Hawken and get rid of the F2P scheme.  It really is an amazingly fun game!

Early Access Review

Fantastic game.  Great gameplay, fairly well balanced, beautiful graphics, encourages teamwork, decent maps and a fair number of them.  The  best AND worst part of this game are that its F2P.  A bit too grindy for me.  I'd like to purchase more mechs, but with the cost of upgrading using XP based credits, i don't see myself playing this game for too long.  I'd be more inclined to spend money on cosmetics in these F2P games if they made more of the actual game accessable without spending money (they are free-to-play, yes?).  They're certainly not helping themselves with the current grind-or-pay-to-play model they're using.

P.S.  Here's a little write-up about F2P models in general, and the authors opinion of them, with specific examples given in relation to Hawken.  Sums up fairly well why I dislike F2P. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I built my first custom computer back in April, and HAWKEN was one of the first games I downloaded for it. I was immediately playing very well, which surprised me, because although I've played console FPS's well for years, I was mediocre in the brief earlier attempts I'd made at playing FPS titles with a mouse and keyboard.

Some will say that HAWKEN is lacking in game modes, which is sort of true, but I don't mind it, because all the game modes present are solid and fun. It's not like certain other FPS titles that have two or three times the game modes with most of the extra ones just feeling gimmicky and/or pointless. There isn't a whole lot of diversity in weapons or modifications with a lot of overlap across mechs, but I don't mind this either, because each mech still has it's own unique feel, and the overlap in equipment allows you to transition to new mechs more easily.

I recommend this game 100% to anyone with an interest in FPS's. The starting mech is plenty capable for combat, and in my opinion, the grind to get enough in-game credit to purchase new mechs is not bad at all. Adhesive Games should be applauded for the free-to-play structure of this game. I'm good enough and play enough that I didn't really need to spend more than a few real dollars on the game for cosmetic items; but I love the game so much I purchased both the Mercenary and Prosk packs just to support the developer!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not sure where the mech trend is coming from. As a person that's played through all Mechwarrior games by Microsoft I can say this game is fairly fun and a bump up futuristic realisation of the same genre and concept, although incorporated in present day features.

Pros:
- Mechwarrior shooter.
- Gameplay feels solid.
- Balanced stats.
- Action-packed fights.
- Broad customization and gear boosts.
- Nice graphics, but not very demanding.

Cons:
- Pay to win.
- Gets repetitive.

I played Mechwarrior in the past and was a small fan. The games were great and it's surprising to see so many new multiplayer games popping up with a similar genre.

The gameplay on first notice felt solid. The tutorial was alright to explain me the ins and outs of the game from menu and stats to gearing and battle. And I was quickly able to jump into the game. The graphics were nice yet at the same time not very demanding. I noticed how textures would load overtime; how camouflage was first very digital-ish cloudy and then gained more detailed gradually. Texture processing was thus flawless.

The stats felt balanced. Tried all classes and didn't really feel like one class was underpowered in comparison to another or so. I had equal odds even as a beginner. All classes ofcourse had their ups and downs and it took a while to get a hang of the gameplay but that's about it.

The battles were very intense and the maps were great. One point you're running around in a pack of mechs, another moment you arrive in a fight split-second and see bullets buzzing by your cockpit and run to avoid explosions, constant metal clanking and people shooting through the skies in leaps using their jetpacks.

The customization was nice. A lot of different items to boost different stats and adapt your mech to your personalized gameplay. There's an alright level of freedom as to how you play the game and this allows for different combos in classes. - One thing I didn't like was the store though. From the moment you get on you're just bombed with commercial ads about buying things using real money, and it's just really easy to get a hold of these items and people with money just gain a significant advantage purchasing exclusives, so you're basically going to end up being forced to pay regardless. If not you're just stressed out with ads so much you'll buy at one point anyway.

I feel the gameplay is just going to get repetitive. I closed the game after about an hour, but then again I'm not much of an online FPS player. I think the game can satisfy a very broad audience and might moreso be a little underrated for its quality, in comparison to games such as Titanfall.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Placed a hologram in a corner and put a turret under it at a missle capture point, stood in the other corner defending the point in my giant C-class incinerator mech and blew up mechs who spent the entire time repeatedly coming in and firing at the hologram fruitlessly .

Jumped off a bridge and landed on a tiny A class, killing it. 10/10, Would squash flat again.

In all Seriousness, the mechs play very differently from each other, especially with weapon loadouts changing how you handle them, some more than others. but all of them are still very balanced. They have ideal situations where they perform optimaly, you try to avoid your enemies optimal situations and create your own.

team work and skill is key. No one weapon or mech is the one all, none are overpowered. They are all contextual variations that perform well in certain situations with their own disadvantages. Strategies like flanking, holding lines, defending each other, creating ambushes and covering fire are actually possible and rewarding.

this game seriously needs more love.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Haven't had this much fun in a Mech in a very long time. Gritty fast and raw battles, amazing visuals, and a combat system that is much more dependant on skill than your wallet.

If you loved the old Mechwarrior I and II games, fire this up.

The only big negative with Hawken so far is that it wants to double-dip" players on the standard Bonus Exp
date: Bonus Credits monthly modifiers.  Unlike most (MW
hoursPlayed: etc)  Hawken wants you to buy both exp and credit bonuses seperately. There is no "monthly" gold membership type option.  If you want EXP and Credit bonuses for a month get ready to pay 30 or 40 bucks for it.\n\nYou can still play it F2P but the speed at which you get exp and money in this game is insanely slow
voteText: much worse than most f2p games. Also
helpfulPercent: Items and Internals are not interchangable; if you spend a week griding to buy a droppable machine gun turret for your sniper mech your going to have to spend another week grinding to get the same turret for your brawler. Early Access Review

The best free-to-play game I've played so far. It's a really fast paced game with small maps. I think this game is similar to Titanfall but there's no infantry in Hawken. Now it is still in beta but I haven't seen a single bug yet. The dev team is continuously adding new content to the game, and now we even have a co-op game mode. The level of customization in this game is insane... The graphics are extremely nice too (although I'm playing on medium settings).

And the best thing about this game is that it is not pay to win! You only have to pay for things that does not change the gamplay. For example camo paints and other cosmetic things. Everything else is unlockable by Hawken Credits (in-game money).

Right now I'm a level 15 pilot with a rank 4 Brawler (Type-C heavy). I have played a lot with this game beafore it was released on steam, so I think I have  earned that mech with about 20 hours of gaming so it's not that time consuming, but there's plenty of stuff to unlock.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I came into HAWKEN as a player who has enjoyed many other mech shooters: Mech Warrior, ChromeHounds and Armored Core to name a few. At first, I was somewhat unimpressed with the tutorial, thinking the game would be rather straightforward and have a low skill cap. In my third match online, I quickly realized that not everything was as it seemed. No matter how much or little firepower or how high or low your armor amount, you could win fights against all odds if you possessed skill and forethought. The dodging and boosting is executed in such a way that even heavy mechs /can/ dodge effectively. Obviously not as well as lightweights, but that's why you have double the armor.

My first impression was entirely wrong. Stepping into the various gamemodes, I realized quickly that the modes appeal to a wide audience. For casual gamers who dislike competition, there is a coop mode where you can fight waves of bots and still earn the same currency and experience earned in other game types like Team Deathmatch, if not slower. Team Deathmatch is great because a few great players can curb a few players who are struggling. Then there is matches such as Seige, where it requires immense teamwork and has little room for error.

As to what I enjoy in the game, it's simple. The players are so diverse and the mechs are so flexible as to allow a great variety of playstyles. There's a stealth mech that can easily run into a firefight and disappear just as quickly for hit and run tactics, or there's a way to set up traps with your stealth mech and take down multiple targets by luring them. Even the large powerhouses have styles, where they can stand back and lob explosives across the map or get up close and attempt to beat others into submission with greater accuracy and firepower. What truly makes this shine is that the balance is so well done. Overall, at least, I still hate Scouts and think they need some balancing.

My literal only complaint is that the currency is slow to earn. I understand this is a gimmick to make one want to spend their real life cash to get what they want faster, but it seems slow even for that. I often have to play 10-20 matches to afford accessories for my mechs, and a good 30-40 for an entirely new mech, which will be entirely vanilla when I get it. But that's a great cash-grab, as it's the first free to play I've paid for in a long time.

Overall, I give it a 9/10, not that my opinion means much. It's a wonderful game and there's a lot to learn and explore (In terms of in-game tactics, this is certainly a MOBA-esque game). I'll be playing a lot more of this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not sure where the mech trend is coming from. As a person that's played through all Mechwarrior games by Microsoft I can say this game is fairly fun and a bump up futuristic realisation of the same genre and concept, although incorporated in present day features.

Pros:
- Mechwarrior shooter.
- Gameplay feels solid.
- Balanced stats.
- Action-packed fights.
- Broad customization and gear boosts.
- Nice graphics, but not very demanding.

Cons:
- Pay to win.
- Gets repetitive.

I played Mechwarrior in the past and was a small fan. The games were great and it's surprising to see so many new multiplayer games popping up with a similar genre.

The gameplay on first notice felt solid. The tutorial was alright to explain me the ins and outs of the game from menu and stats to gearing and battle. And I was quickly able to jump into the game. The graphics were nice yet at the same time not very demanding. I noticed how textures would load overtime; how camouflage was first very digital-ish cloudy and then gained more detailed gradually. Texture processing was thus flawless.

The stats felt balanced. Tried all classes and didn't really feel like one class was underpowered in comparison to another or so. I had equal odds even as a beginner. All classes ofcourse had their ups and downs and it took a while to get a hang of the gameplay but that's about it.

The battles were very intense and the maps were great. One point you're running around in a pack of mechs, another moment you arrive in a fight split-second and see bullets buzzing by your cockpit and run to avoid explosions, constant metal clanking and people shooting through the skies in leaps using their jetpacks.

The customization was nice. A lot of different items to boost different stats and adapt your mech to your personalized gameplay. There's an alright level of freedom as to how you play the game and this allows for different combos in classes. - One thing I didn't like was the store though. From the moment you get on you're just bombed with commercial ads about buying things using real money, and it's just really easy to get a hold of these items and people with money just gain a significant advantage purchasing exclusives, so you're basically going to end up being forced to pay regardless. If not you're just stressed out with ads so much you'll buy at one point anyway.

I feel the gameplay is just going to get repetitive. I closed the game after about an hour, but then again I'm not much of an online FPS player. I think the game can satisfy a very broad audience and might moreso be a little underrated for its quality, in comparison to games such as Titanfall.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I greatly have enjoyed Hawken for a variety of reasons. It reminds me of an old mech game on Sega Dreamcast that I played as a teenager. The game itself has great players who tend to be friendly and helpful if asked for assistance which can make all the difference for a newbie. The in-game tutorial is also rather fantastic because it works with whatever settings you made for your movement keys, rather than forcing you to work with the default key settings. The game also is excellent in the fact you can completely customize the mech's looks, as well as having plenty of different mechs to experiment with to fit your gameplay style.

The negative side of things are it can be difficult to change things in the garage in-between death matches with maybe only a minute before the next match starts. You have to go all the way back out to the garage to do any heavy modifications to your mech. That means unless you mark people you're playing with as friends, then you can't go back to the same game you left. Also, it can be hard to earn credits to pay for new mechs early on in the game. Especially if you don't have the right mech to play in or if you don't have a good run of luck with more experienced players. I will definitely be adding more to my review as I play more.

Currently, I'd give this game a 8.8/10 or a 9/10. I really don't have a lot to complain about, and I do greatly enjoy the game when I do get the chance to play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As the description says, Hawken is a mech FPS stylized in an arena-shooter fashion--much like the Quake and Unreal Tournament days. There are plenty of pros and cons in this game--and they, while in my opinion wash out evenly, might make or break the experience for some players.

What's great:
-Solid Control Feel: You can really grasp the titanic weight of the mechs as they move...trembling the ground as they trod and wrecking scenery objects like toys...really giving a realistic sense of the scope of the machine you are piloting. There area wide variety of activatable tools and abilities, which take some time (and a proper mouse with lots of mappable buttons) to learn and use instictively, but all add to the feel of self-extension that mechs are meant to convey.

-Intuitive Cockpit UI: The most recent version of the game's interface is a big improvement on the old versions; gagues for Heat, Fuel, Health, and Weaponry are integrated in such a way that they tell you what they are supposed to without being distracting...or hard to find. Most everything is centered around the targeting reticle, allowing you maximum information without taking essential attention away from the fight.

-Mech Class Balance: Mechs are broken up into weight class; Light A, Medium B, and Heavy C. Each have thier specialty, be it superior movement, defensive power, offensive power, or a mix of the three. For every strength, there is an equal and opposite weakness, and that makes for a well-balanced, and fair selection of equipment.

-Free To Play, but not Pay-To-Win: This is invariably the Free to Play catch; players with deep pockets can arm themselves to the teeth with real money, while free players are left with lackluster table scraps. Meteor has seemingly gone to great lengths to make sure that using real currency to upgrade your equipment only buys you time, not power. Everything (yes, everything) except cosmetics can eventually be bought with in-game credits, making it truly free to play...and free to win; with enough skill.

-Graphics: Built on the Unreal Engine, the game boasts the tried-and-true Unreal mix of grittiness and polish. Dynamic shadows and volumetric lighting cast in contrast beautifully across the torn and mechanized landscape, with huge, immersive skyboxes. The weapons and mechs are an intricate spiderweb of metal and wiring, moving and operating with an acute attention to mechanical intricacy and detail; while giving a clear impression of the high technological advancement, yet low budget of Illial's inhabitants. Both are held together with steel straps, makeshift parts, and shoddy patchwork, all adding to dynamic of the post-apocalyptic backstory. The game also has support for PhysX particles, and true stereoscopic Oculus 3D; almost unheard of for a beta.

---------------------------------------------------------------------

What's not so great:
-Matchmaking Is Poorly Organized: While the game offers a fair lineup of mechs, the matchmaking queue does not sort out players by pilot rank or mech level. This ends up in very unfair matches, pitting more experienced players with better equipment against new initiates. On either side of the table, one might find themselves bored to tears from lack of challenge, or frustrated to no end from losing every match and getting cheated out of any significant amount of credits, thanks to this major problem.

-Lack of Map Variety: All gamemodes share the same 8 maps, and they get old, quick. Old arena shooters often sported 15-20 maps for each game mode...and while these maps are spectacular, and are no doubt difficult to build in volume, more are going to have to be introduced to keep players interested.

-Currency Aquisition: While the unfair Pay-To-Win aspect has respectably omitted from this title, in game credits are hard to come by without a significant investment of time. A winning match yields close to 450$, each lasting 10 minutes. Mechs are 7-12,700$, weapons are 2-6000$, and items are 800-5000$. The math stacks in favor of microtransactions, and that may turn off players already frustrated with previous FTP experience.

All in all, Hawken is a solid game, and will be even more so, given some improvement. I definitely reccomend it, and you have nothing to lose by trying it. If you like FPS's give it a shot!

I started playing HAWKEN when it was realeased in closed beta. This is not your typical Mech game,
It's not a slow moving game like MW is. I found it very easy to hop into the game and with the
tutorials provided and not feel beat on. Now the game does have ingame voice and it works well. The problem lies in that you hardly hear any one using it. I will say the rare accasion that I have had 3 or 4 players talking we kicked ♥♥♥.
With all the changes through the bata and the new stuff here on Steam the game has seemed to take on a new life for me. First the Free aspect hit home, you know the FREE word. Now the part where you can use money to get things was a worry for me but it was mostly skins and body parts.

This game is alot of fun and I am glad it found its way to Steam.

There are 5 diffrent types of game play,
Deathmatch- This is pretty much a given. Shoot every thing that moves.

Team Deathmatch- Ok so you have team mates now. This could be a really good thing but don't hold your breath.
Unless you have a team of people you know and play games with you will be in a hell of a mess. Public servers are
a pain in the ♥♥♥.. But there is a slim chance you can come together as a team and win.

Missle Assault- Capture and hold the silo's until the enemy base is destroyed.

Seige- You have to gather energy and then return to feed the bomb. the team that does it first wins.

Co-op- Now this is a 4 person slugfest. 25 rounds and man after 10 rounds you had better have your poop in a group. The mech AI gets smart and retreat and hide and heal. Oh they also seem to use teamwork...

As for the Mechs there are guides out there that cover it better then I ever could.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

HAWKEN is a wonderful multiplayer game that emulates the feel of stomping around in a combat mech. Succesfully piloting your mech will take a lot of skill- preventing yourself from overheating, dodging and taking evasive action, and knowing the strengths and weaknesses of both your and your opponent's mechs are all key to victory. The graphics are incredible, the gameplay is visceral and oh-so rewarding, the audio really makes you feel like bullets are pinging off your hull as you stomp towards your enemy, minigun spinning up and rocket launcher flinging its payload at said opponent.

Yes, microtransactions ARE part of the game, but, barring cosmetic items, there is almost nothing you can buy with real money that can't be earned in the game, and the starting mech (though unimpressive in appearence) is remarkably well-rounded and balanced. The mechs are varied and useful only for certain situations- spending money to instantly buy the biggest mech in the game and unlock all its weapons immediately won't help you win. Knowing the strengths of your mech and its weapons, and how to use them against the enemy, is what will make you do well in HAWKEN.

I do spend money on this game, but what money you put in will be well-spent. Mechs (in the in-game currency to buy them outright) are roughly $10, and another $5-$10 will take you far in terms of customization. You can also buy some of the various bundles here, which will serve you well as a place to start off from.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hawken may just be one of my favourite multiplayer first person shooters ever, and I'm not just saying that because I'm actually pretty decent at it.

The premise is fairly simple. You're a mech pilot. There's another bunch of pilots working for a shady mega corporation or something, and you gotta blow them up, ideally before they blow you up. Got all that? Okay, you're good to go. Don't expect Steel Battalion level of complexity here. You aim with the mouse, boost with shift, and have a couple extra buttons for items (grenades, turrets and the like) and that's pretty much it. Surviving gun fights is about keeping your sights trained on your enemy whilst remaining mobile and keeping an eye on your fuel and heat gauges. Keeping a cool head and balancing all of this is integral to winning fights, moreso than twitch reactionary timing.

There are several mechs to select, each with different weapons (with a couple of alternatives) and a special class ability to give them the edge in battle. Aside from that, you have a few aesthetic customisation options, but you're extremely limited unless you're willing to shell out some real life dough to make your ideal death machine stand out in a crowd. The positive side of this is that all of those aesthetic options are pretty much the only things unavailable to non-playing players. Of course, paying customers can buy their way ahead of the competition, but they won't get anything that a normal player can unlock over time.

Customising the loadout of your mech is a fun process. There's no right answer to how you should configure your machine, so it's entirely up to your playstyle. One of my mechs, a Berserker, is extremely light and agile, but hits hard, at the cost of defence. It's tailored to win fights with guerilla tactics through the use of internals that give me the ability to dash and quick turn in air. For long-term survival, it's outfitted with a turret and an auto-heal that slowly repairs my mech over time outside of combat. This is just one of many combinations, one that's perfect for me, but sub-optimal for a different kind of player. Finding what works best for you and creating mechs that fit that style of play is a big part of the fun in Hawken.

The combat feels balanced for the most part, whether you're playing conservatively as a member of an organised (or disorganised, from most of my personal experiences) team or an opportunistic lone wolf in team deathmatches and free for all games. Knowledge of the different classes, quick-thinking and clever tactics are what separate scrap from salvagers in this game, and I rarely felt cheated. It's rare to find a multiplayer game that isn't a twitchy, Mountain Dew-fuelled, rage inducing blur, but this is one of those games. That isn't, I mean. It's a blast to play, and I sincerely wish it had a bigger player base.

So it's like Titanfall, if you spent all your time in the mechs. Sorta.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, now that I have a decent amount of time in HAWKEN, I might as well wright a decent review for it.  First of all, there are very few shooters that I can think of that are like it: a first-person, fast paced mech shooter.  The concept is very interesting, the mech designs are unique and thought out, and the weapons are (for the most part) balanced.  The sound design is fantastic, with missiles whooshing, bullets pinging and ringing, Thumping explosions are very satisfying, the feet of your mech thumping methodically on the ground, ad the ambience of the environment surrounding you during rare moments of silence.  The graphics are steller, and even though im only running it on a mix of medium/high settings, it still looks gorgeous, considering it is several years old already.

I would talk about how the devs have abandoned the game (they did), but that doesn't matter now, as a new studio has purchased the I.P., and from the recent posts on the HAWKEN Facebook page, it seems like the new devs have their heads screwed on straight about the destiny of HAWKEN. Having been playing HAWKEN on and off since Alpha 2, I have rekindled hope for this game to become something great again. I just hope they nerf the Incinerator and Scout :)

The game has several game modes, inculding the classic Team Deathmatch as well as free-for-all Deathmatch.  It has a special co-op mode for fighting waves of A.I. drones with 3 of your friends, and a mode called Siege (don't play this mode, it is either super easy or a pitiful smackdown for you), that involves collecting energy to lauch a 'battleship' which then attacked the enemy's base; the first team to have their base destroyed loses.

The small community of driven players have kept this game alive, and the new devs say they are going to use us to help shape HAWKEN's future, so who know what happens next?

8.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is amazing. This is everything I want out of a mech fighter. It feels authentic, tough and dirty, and every fight is explosive and grueling.
There's a VERY wide variety of mechs available (about 20 unique types) with customizable weapons, items, attachments, and cosmetics.

As for the free to play model, it follows it pretty well. New mechs and items can be purchased with in game points that take a decent time to build up or you can buy with real points while different mechs rotate free to play (a similar model to league of legends.)
Cosmetics mostly are only available for real cash, though some can be gained with leveling up.

My one complaint is that this game is not incredibly optimized and my laptop which runs valve games on highest settings at 120fps and most others at 60fps, this one is only 30-40. It does not impede my enjoyment and the gravel, debris, dirt flying in the air slightly lowering the fps is worth it for the effect (but if your computer isn't as powerful you might need to lower certain settings.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is amazing, it's like re-living good ol' MechWarrior except it has original and innovative mechanics of it's own.

Each mech has its own special skill, for example the Reaper.
A light frontline sniper build having an ability called 'Precision Overdrive' which grants its user increased accuracy and precision for a short period.

They also come with a cute little repair drone that fixes you up when you need it!
However it is recommended that you stay out of combat while doing so, your Mech is rendered immobile and unable to attack.

What I don't like are some of the maps, specifically Uptown and Origin.
Their designs can cause a lot of problems navigating, you honestly can get confused whether that hole you're boosting towards is even an entrance/exit to a tunnel.

Other than that this game is amazing and has loads of potential, just try and keep your cash close to you.
The items available for purchasing in-game are kind of...costly.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's not really a mech game imo.
Unreal Tournament with mech skins.

You get two guns at once, with the right one being able to do a secondary attack: like detonate rockets mid flight, lock target, etc.
Some items to use: shields, mini turrets, mines, bombs etc
And each mech has a specialist ability: 1 way Shield bubble, Rapid Heal, extra damage or armour, turret modes etc.
Mechs have varying basic stats like HP, Armour, Movement, Fuel (ability to dodge, boost forward and jump/hover)

Gameplay is tight, and the art style is nice, animations are really fluid and the level design is about right. Some have a lot of space, some tunnels, other with a mix and jump pads.
Few different game modes, and customization of bots.

You can play fine as F2P but it does mean waiting to gain mech xp which is tied to the specific weapon upgrades/variations you can take on that specific shell.

EDIT. Also costs you a lot to get basic internals (passive perks) after initially buying a mech so beware when grabbign the shiny new one that you won't have a lot of the things the trial mechs have equipped.

My analogy is based off the fact that there is no hardpoints, or localized damage model. Only 2 guns in hand and you can regen ingame when out of combat. There is heat" but this is just a limiter on firepower as there is no ammo: again more unreal than Mechwarrior imo

Customization comes down to limited percentile perks (slight reductions or additions in set areas)
Appesrance customization is just that.
This makes balance nice
date: and you know what to expect by the look of the mechs."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I started playing HAWKEN when it was realeased in closed beta. This is not your typical Mech game,
It's not a slow moving game like MW is. I found it very easy to hop into the game and with the
tutorials provided and not feel beat on. Now the game does have ingame voice and it works well. The problem lies in that you hardly hear any one using it. I will say the rare accasion that I have had 3 or 4 players talking we kicked ♥♥♥.
With all the changes through the bata and the new stuff here on Steam the game has seemed to take on a new life for me. First the Free aspect hit home, you know the FREE word. Now the part where you can use money to get things was a worry for me but it was mostly skins and body parts.

This game is alot of fun and I am glad it found its way to Steam.

There are 5 diffrent types of game play,
Deathmatch- This is pretty much a given. Shoot every thing that moves.

Team Deathmatch- Ok so you have team mates now. This could be a really good thing but don't hold your breath.
Unless you have a team of people you know and play games with you will be in a hell of a mess. Public servers are
a pain in the ♥♥♥.. But there is a slim chance you can come together as a team and win.

Missle Assault- Capture and hold the silo's until the enemy base is destroyed.

Seige- You have to gather energy and then return to feed the bomb. the team that does it first wins.

Co-op- Now this is a 4 person slugfest. 25 rounds and man after 10 rounds you had better have your poop in a group. The mech AI gets smart and retreat and hide and heal. Oh they also seem to use teamwork...

As for the Mechs there are guides out there that cover it better then I ever could.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

HAWKEN is a wonderful multiplayer game that emulates the feel of stomping around in a combat mech. Succesfully piloting your mech will take a lot of skill- preventing yourself from overheating, dodging and taking evasive action, and knowing the strengths and weaknesses of both your and your opponent's mechs are all key to victory. The graphics are incredible, the gameplay is visceral and oh-so rewarding, the audio really makes you feel like bullets are pinging off your hull as you stomp towards your enemy, minigun spinning up and rocket launcher flinging its payload at said opponent.

Yes, microtransactions ARE part of the game, but, barring cosmetic items, there is almost nothing you can buy with real money that can't be earned in the game, and the starting mech (though unimpressive in appearence) is remarkably well-rounded and balanced. The mechs are varied and useful only for certain situations- spending money to instantly buy the biggest mech in the game and unlock all its weapons immediately won't help you win. Knowing the strengths of your mech and its weapons, and how to use them against the enemy, is what will make you do well in HAWKEN.

I do spend money on this game, but what money you put in will be well-spent. Mechs (in the in-game currency to buy them outright) are roughly $10, and another $5-$10 will take you far in terms of customization. You can also buy some of the various bundles here, which will serve you well as a place to start off from.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is absolutely fantastic and it was well worth the long wait on development. I've been following this game since Team Hawken formed and showed off their first working prototype, and they've received a lot of help and support to make this game the absolute best it can be.
This game takes a very unique approach to blending Mechs and FPS shooters, and puts you in the pilot seat, where you will feel VERY comfortable. Movement, physics, and the way your mech reacts to your commands feels amazing. Boosting and dodging and flying through the air is exhilerating!
Overall art design for this project is top-notch with MUCH attention to detail. Sound design is great, explosive effects and catchy menu music feel perfect; while the insane graphics options allow you to appropriately melt your eyeballs while simultaneously save your hardware from melting (Vsync is your friend, make sure it's enabled).
As far as betas go, let alone F2P, this game is absolutely worth anyone's time and I highly recommend it.
I've had my time with countless shooters, totalling countless hours, from CS 1.5 to Source and CSGO, Halo 2 multiplayer, CoD MW2 and so forth; I've spent too much time in the online arena yet Hawken feels fresh and exciting to me. I come back to play a few rounds almost daily.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis Game Has So Much Potential! It Is Truly A Work Of Art, And Deserves The Best. Due To Lack Of Blood/Gore, No Shooting People, And Funny Animations, This Game Could Suit Those Who Are Not Exactly 17 And Up. reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nHawken is a very intense game where you fight as mechs with two weapons. I was a little iffy about trying this game out for the fact I thought it was just going to be explosion after explosion with not much to offer with gameplay. Well I was happily surprised by what I found. This game delivers a rush of energy many have failed to give. Keeping still in this game is the one thing you never want to do and it is hard to adjust from other FPS I have played in the past. The community in this game is pretty chill from what I have seen so far and I have not found a single person that has be rude to me. The thing I like is the fact that there is Co-op modes, which I would like to see more for there are only two, and the AI is not dumb, I have been in lots of matches where the bots win. Another thing I was worried about was I thought this was going to be a PTW game. This brings me to the one problem with the game, progression in this game takes TIME. Before you can get a new mech you need a LOT of HC (Hawken Credits). If you don't like slow progression, then this game might not be for you, but I have the standard mech and it has been doing just fine for my needs, even if it looks derpy I don't care, I don't see it unless I die. In regards to the progression I can't complain though, they need money and if you want to progress faster you can pay. I would pay for this game, so I plan on putting in $60 and pretending that it was a normal game that I had to purchase. To most gamers I would definitely recommend this game to all. It is free to play so there is no harm in trying it out :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A fast paced and well written mech based FPS, very impressive for an open beta. Think about CS and Mechwarrior rolled into one package.

Pros:
1.Great visuals.
2.Clear HUD which fits very well into the game.
3. Quick to get into. Tutorials teach you everything you need to get started and leave no guessing.
4. Sound is great.
5. Quite intuitive and easy to grasp controls.

Cons:
1. Microtransactions are always a bit iffy for me. Thankfully with Hawken these are used mainly for cosmetic changes though, and if you're wanting to access mechs or weapons earlier. So really all in all this is just a preferential taste.
2. Open beta means certain features or balance issues might be flawed or missing but the developers seem to be releasing constant updates which is a very appreciated plus.

So would I recommend this? Absolutely. Get it and start blowing your friends to bits already.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nConsole-FPS-inspired FPS with enough mech stuff to make you feel like it's actually a mech game. It's F2P which means it has F2P's trappings, but it doesn't have any of those horrifying diminishing-return mechanics that, say, World of Tanks does, and the power level differences between levelled mechs and unleveled mechs are reasonably sober. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Graphics are pretty sweet, as is the gameplay. Each of the mechs are fairly unique, and it's awesome to see the mix of different types work well together in team games. Customization options look very nice and great detail.

I suck posterior at online FPS's usually, but the crazy thing about Hawken is that even though I get stomped 9 games out of 10, I keep coming back for more. Best mech game I've played in years - though to be fair the last one I played was Mechwarrior 2 Mercenaries back in the 90s.

I rate it 3 Gwyneth Paltrows.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

HAWKEN is a quick action close quarters combat FPS game with many interesting game mechanics. It is by no means a Mechwarrior clone nor does it have the same strategic gameplay though It is safe to say the developers of HAWKEN were inspired by the Mechwarrior series. HAWKEN also has support for the Oculus Rift, I haven't tried it myself but apparently it works extremely well and is a very nice proof of concept title. As for controls and combat, pretty full proof from what I can see. The gameplay with the mechs feels pretty logical in the way the mech feels when you move and the fast combat is also pretty fluid once you are familiar with the controls, the overall gameplay feels.... Realistic? If mechs were real it would be.

Like the vast majority of Free to Play titles, this game does include a lot of microtransactions though I can safely say they are not as bad as some games *cough* APB: Reloaded *cough* since they do not push the consumer to purchase in-game points. You can buy almost any item using microtransactions, including weapons and mechs, which is a bit of a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ but it is still very enjoyable and entertaining to play none the less.
Another thing that will put many players off is the grinding involved, there is tons and the only way around it is to, of course, use the microtransaction system. I personally am fine with grinding as long as it is satisfying and actually gets me somewhere, which it does so I'm all smiles.

I do have some personal issues that I would like to say, apparently there is a feature to 'Test drive' mechs before purchase but most mech types are not eligible for tests and so it feels like your trying to buy groceries with a blind fold on. Also there has been a significant change since the alpha stage, it almost feels like the games atmosphere has changed dramatically since then. Whether this is a good thing or bad is still to be answered, some of you alpha buddies may notice once the game is released to the public.
One last thing, if you ever play this game and you're going to buy a mech, please, PLEASE make sure you are buying the right mech. I made one mistake of spending 12,000 points on a mech by mistake and finding out it was the worst mech in the game. If you compare the price to how much you make in a single match (150 average) then you can understand it's a huge dent in the resources I saved up.

All in all, I think it's a pretty good game. It's free, it's relatively small and it'll be out soon so go try it out!
